AL:WM
Ottawa,
May 10, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant a cheque for $5503.80 in part payment of the March quarter earnings of the St. George's Residential School was sent to you on the 4th instant and it is hoped that it has reached you by this time.

We are operating at the present time on Governor General's Warrant and consequently the funds at our disposal will only permit payment of approximately 80% of the March quarter earnings. Further funds will be available after the opening of Parliament.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

A few days ago I wrote asking for an advance on this quarter's earnings to an amount of $2000.00, and since that time, and after a period of illness, I have been able to check up and find that due to uncontrollable factors, it is necessary for me to go back to you for an additional advance of $2500.00. To ensure the necessary supply of clothing, I was obliged, because of conditions, to put in a year's supply, which bill for clothing amounts to some $2000.00. There is also a bill for boots and rubbers to an amount of some $400.00, and together with these our coal supply must be taken care of at this time of the year.

This, as you will note, will total $4500.00 in advance on a possible per capita earning return of $7,100.00; thus as it were spending in advance the greater part of the quarter's earnings. While this is so, there is no need to worry, as while I do expect a deficit, it will not be over $1500.00, and this could come to us, if available, from the New England grant to arrive during the quarter ending March 31st, in time to take care of salaries for the month of March.

I am, therefore, contemplating a deficit on the year's work of $1500.00. I should be extremely grateful if the additional cheque could be forwarded to me as soon as possible so that I can take care of the condensed bills which conditions demanded this year. In other years I have been able to spread them out. I sincerely trust that I am not asking too much, and that you will see the necessity which has arisen and for which I wish to make provision.

Yours very obediently,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I had looked forward to a cheque in advance on this mail, and this has not come to hand. The fact that my cheques have been held up, through no fault of my own, is creating a rather embarrassing financial position.

I shall be obliged to explain to my staff and also to dry goods and other firms with whom I carry on school business that my cheques from the Department are somewhat delayed. I should be really glad if you would give immediate attention to these advances as I am really in need of cash with which to carry on. Prices for farm products have been very low this year, and I have not realized the cash subsidy which at this time of the year should be in. As you know, there is only the farm to rely upon, and unless the Department comes to my aid I cannot take care of my accounts. The Department has been very particular heretofor in specifying that I must take care of school expenditures through advanced grants. May I have same, please?

Yours very obediently,

[Signature]

Mr. Hoey -

Mr. Graham promises that this cheque will be sent forward by AIR MAIL TODAY

Dear Mr. Hoey,

To date, the cheque from the Department for the per capita earnings for the quarter ending March 31st, 1941 has not been received, and I was just wondering if this might have gone astray in the mail.

There has been delay in receiving the per capita grant for the quarter ending March 31st in previous years, but we have not had to wait so long as this for the cheque on other occasions. The quarterly returns were forwarded by the school to the Indian Agent, Lytton, on April 2nd.

Anything which you can do for us in this matter will be very greatly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Lyttton, B.C., August 14 1941.

Mr. A. Strang, Indian Agent,
LYTTON, B.C.,

Dear Mr. Strang: This is to advise you that the following outstanding accounts as listed by Mr. Coleman, Inspector of Indian Agencies, in his July 15 financial statement of this school have been attended to. Cheques have gone forward today to the various firms, and in each case I have asked for the receipt in quadruplicate for government purposes.

It was necessary for me to hold back $100 in the account of Gillespie Grain Co and $200 in the case of Vancouver Inland Coal, since the $3000 sent to me by the Department in Ottawa was not enough to cover all outstanding accounts, since the accounts receivable as list on the July 15th statement have not been forthcoming to date. I trust the Department will realize it was necessary for me to leave certain accounts as not fully cleared off, as in the case of the two just mentioned above.

I might add also there was $36.14 Indian wages for farm workers here in July due and had to give these attention, since the Indians were very restless over the matter.

Accounts paid as per list of Mr. Coleman, July 15 are:

| Name                        | Amount |
|-----------------------------|--------|
| J. H. Anthony               | $14.55 |
| Ed. Sch Trustees            | 37.75  |
| Stanley Brock               | 101.88 |
| Buckerfields                | 281.68 |
| Brett's Garage              | 37.75  |
| Can Industries              | 137.15 |
| Mark Dummond                | 77.44  |
| Dammer and Sons             | 92.90  |
| Gov't Tel Co                | 8.46   |
| Grassie Co                  | 3.00   |
| Gen Ed. Reg. Ed.            | 7.25   |
| Gillespie Gr. Co.           | 229.96 |
| T. Kearney                  | 19.00  |
| Lytton Box Co               | 63.41  |
| Lytton Garage               | 328.10 |

May I also draw your attention to the fact that not all outstanding accounts were in at the time Mr. Coleman, Inspector of Agencies made his audit here. Additional—there are the following accounts at present outstanding and not yet submitted to the Department in Ottawa. The delay is in the fact that Rev. Lett must in each case...
certify the bill is in order before submit it to Mr. Coleman for transmitting to Ottawa. I have sent on the following outstanding accounts for Mr. Lett's signature and trust he will attend to them soon, so the matter might be settled.

- Leckie Shoe Co., Account—many months old——$548.76
- Kelly Douglas Co., year old account——$332.45
- Mark Dummond Account—This is additional to their account of $77.44 on July 15 statement

Vancouver Motors ———————————————— $13.95
Consolidated Optical Company ——————————— $243
Singer Sewing Machine Company ——————————— $124.00
B. R. Meat Market Company ——————————— $33.00
Staff Salaries ——————————— $640.00

In the case of the staff salaries Mr. Lett paid staff on the yearly basis of 11 months if returning for another year. It may be however, he will consider only one half ($320) belongs to his term of office, till July 15, in such case only $320 would be staff wages owing to July 15.

Apart from above, $465.56 regular wages for July to staff is now due. These include two farm hands, manual training instructor, who has worked here all summer, cook, engineer and office worker. This is for the period of July 16 to July 31. There are also some extra wages for help during the canning period to be paid also.

Therefore if you would kindly notify the Department of the situation here I would greatly appreciate it. The school bank account at present has a debit balance of about $180.00

I shall see to it that all expenditure is kept to the minimum and that proper records are kept for inspection and investigation. Thanking you for your valuable help and assistance to me, I remain,

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Acting Principal.
Lytton, B.C., August 15, 1941.

Sir,

With reference to Departmental letter dated July 30, 1941, I beg to enclose herewith a statement from Mr. Noel Stewart, Acting Principal of the St. George's Indian Residential School, giving the financial standing of the School up to date.

The enclosed statement shows the accounts paid from the $3000.00 received from the Department and outstanding accounts, records of which were not at hand at the time of Inspector Coleman's audit. It is respectfully requested that a further sum be made available as soon as possible to the Acting Principal in order that the outstanding accounts as listed may be paid. I would further suggest that the Department advise Bishop Adams to see that the late Principal endorse the outstanding accounts submitted to him with as little delay as possible as I fear they will receive the same consideration as the originals.

Your obedient servant,

A. Strang,

Ottawa, August 29, 1941.

Dear Sir,

St. George's Indian Residential School
Lytton, B.C.

Under date of June 15th last, when the Department received from the Reverend A.R. Lett, Principal of the above-noted school, a letter tendering his resignation to be effective July 15, 1941, we wrote you requesting that you arrange for Mr. Coleman to visit the school and make an audit of the books and financial records for the period January 1st to July 15th, and also to advise the Department of any outstanding accounts as at that date.

The audit report and statement of outstanding accounts submitted by Mr. Coleman disclosed outstanding accounts amounting to $3,356.87 and accounts receivable of $469.60. Mr. Coleman recommended that an advance of $3,000.00 be made to pay these accounts. This amount was forwarded on July 30, 1941, and on August 14th Mr. Strang, the Indian Agent, furnished the Department with information as to the accounts paid. He also advised of further outstanding accounts of over $2,000.00.

In a letter received from Mr. Coleman on August 16th the outstanding accounts had increased to $2,372.72, and a further letter from Mr. Coleman of August 18th advises of additional accounts amounting to $91.76, while a letter from the Lytton Electric Company Limited encloses a statement showing light and power accounts due as at July 31st, 1941, of $356.32. Indian Agent Strang has recommended a further advance be made in order

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
order that all these accounts may be settled.

The Department is greatly concerned over these accounts. When Mr. T.G. Willis visited this school on January 24, 1941, for the purpose of auditing the records, these outstandings were not disclosed by the Principal and no mention is made by Mr. Willis of them in his report other than that the Principal still found difficulty in financing on the school's earnings. It was only on Mr. Coleman's audit of July 15, 1941, that the outstanding bills were disclosed.

Before advancing any further monies, the Department is requesting that you visit the school and satisfy yourself that the articles purchased as represented by these accounts were necessary for the proper administration of the school and that they have been received at the school, and to determine as far as possible if all the outstandings have been disclosed.

For your information I enclose copies of the following:

Mr. Coleman's letter of July 21 enclosing his report of July 15.
Copy of the account of the Lytton Electric Company Limited.
Mr. Coleman's letter of August 16.
Mr. Strang's letter of August 15 enclosing a letter from Mr. Stewart.
Mr. Coleman's letter of August 18.

On receipt of your report the Department will give consideration to the recommendation of advancing further monies.

Yours truly,

Acting Director.

LWMc/S
Province of BRITISH COLUMBIA

Lytton, B. C., Feb. 19th, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith the Financial Report of St. George's Industrial School from October 1st, 1941, to January 31st, 1942.

The expenditures in household equipment, travel and transportation appear rather high, but are accounted for in the purchase of new furnishings, etc., for the Principal's residence, and transportation from Ontario to British Columbia for himself and family.

I wish to state here that I have had occasion to visit the School quite frequently since the Rev. C. F. Hives has taken charge, and I feel that the improvement in the morale of the whole School to date justifies the change in administration and the Department's choice of a Principal.

I fully appreciate his difficulties in smoothing out unsatisfactory conditions resulting from the previous administration, and promoting goodwill among the personnel without favoritism or any loosening of discipline.

Your obedient servant,

A. Strang,
Indian Agent

AS

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Can.
Ottawa,
February 24, 1942.

Feb. 24, 1942

Dear Sir:

Will you kindly send an advance per capita grant cheque to the amount of $2000.00. I am going to have difficulty in meeting all my obligations before the regular grant comes due. I don't think this difficulty will arise again, but owing to fuel, household equipment and repairs, our expenses have been high during the last quarter.

I would be very much obliged if you will kindly forward cheque any time during the month of March.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hives
Principal

May 8, 1942

Dear Sir:

We are being urged to secure our next Winter's supply of coal fuel. I would like to do this immediately, as we have the accommodation and the time to do it. But the cost is a little more than I could manage right now.

We could handle four car loads, and that amount would be sufficient to see us through next Winter. The cost would be, in our storage, approximately $1200.00.

I would be very much obliged if you would recommend that this amount be advanced from the last quarter of the current year's earnings for our school.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Chas. F. Hives
Principal.

Majoe D.M. McKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Vancouver.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6463, file 888-3, part 3)

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith letter dated the 8th instant received from the Reverend Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School advising that in view of the fuel situation in this province, it is very desirable to secure their School requirements during the slack season of the year but that this would cost the School approximately $1200.00. The expenditure is greater than they could handle from the funds on hand and the Principal would like to know if it is possible to secure an advance on the earnings of the later part of the School year.

If at all possible, I would recommend favourable consideration of the application and would appreciate your advice in the matter.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Enc.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa,
December 1, 1942.

AIR MAIL

Dear Mr. Hives:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, requesting an advance of $2500.00 on the December quarter per capita allowance of the St. George's Indian Residential School. I was hopeful that you would find it unnecessary to make such applications. However, my primary purpose in writing this letter is to point out that there appears to be a tendency on your part to follow the same procedure as caused much of the trouble that existed between your predecessor and the Indian Agent. As previously intimated to you, we are anxious to avoid this state of affairs. I, therefore, suggest that you consult Mr. Strang and have him apply for an advance if necessary. When applying to him you should advise him why you consider an advance is needed.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. C.F. Hives,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.
LYTTON, B.C. Dec. 7, 1942.

I have been approached by the Rev. C.F. Hives, Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School, with the request that he be advanced an amount of $2500.00 on the current quarterly per capita grant.

I am pleased to recommend that this amount be advanced in order that he have sufficient funds on hand at the end of the month to pay his Staff, and would respectfully recommend that the Department give this request favourable consideration.

AIR MAIL.

A. Strang,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, CANADA.
Province of BRITISH COLUMBIA.

Ottawa,
December 15, 1943.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing the October and November financial statements of the Principal of the St. George's Residential School. Please point out to him immediately that the financial statement should be sent at the end of each month. It is rather interesting to review these statements and I would like to bring the following to your attention:

| Date       | Current surplus |
|------------|-----------------|
| September 30 | $6,775.65      |
| October 31   | $5,102.47      |
| November 30   | $4,807.05      |

You will note from the above that the current surplus has dropped over $1,900.00 in the last three months. There may be a good reason for this, but we have had such previous, unfortunate experiences regarding financing at this school that these figures have worried us a little. I might also draw your attention to the fact that the September statement showed salaries in arrears to the amount of $985.00. This item had increased to $1,253.50 at the end of November. The Principal should supply an explanation of why salaries are allowed to become in arrears.

Possibly either you or Inspector Coleman would have an opportunity of discussing the financial situation at this school with the Principal some time in the near future following which interview you should write to me.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Rev. C. F. Hives,
Principal

Dec. 3, 1943
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr Strang:

Our school financial situation is in rather a bad way; and I am writing you to ask if you will kindly place before the Commissioner a request that financial assistance be given us from the New England Company funds, if they are available.

I have tried in every way to meet all our current expenses on the per capita grant allowance, and the return from the farm. Our farming returns this year were very much below normal. The fruit was almost a total failure; the potatoes were blighted; and the yield throughout was light. Salaries have had to be increased in order to obtain a staff of workers in the school. Food and clothing prices have advanced. Owing to epidemics of measles and colds we have had to use nearly two months of fuel extra; and our fuel bill is high in proportion. But the most serious extra expense is the advance in salaries; which we have had to increase 50 and 60 per cent in order to obtain workers.

We urgently require the sum of two thousand dollars to clear ourselves of all debt and pay all salaries by the end of the year.

Will you kindly give this matter your careful consideration; and if at all possible give your approval to my request of financial assistance at this time.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr A. Strang,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.
LYTTON, B.C. December 4, 1943.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, VANGUVER, B.C.

I enclose herewith a duplicate letter written by the Reverend Principal of the St. George's Indian Residential School at Lytton, B.C. in connection with his request for financial assistance for the School.

I beg to draw your attention to the effect that the poor output of the School farm this year can, in no way, be attributed to mismanagement of the farm but is due to lack of assistance and to poor climatic conditions.

I would respectfully recommend that the Reverend Principal's request receive your favourable consideration.

A. Strang,
Indian Agent.

MM.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith a letter dated the 3rd instant addressed to Mr. Indian Agent Strang by the Reverend Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School and Mr. Strang's letter of the 4th instant covering the request of the Principal for a grant of $2,000.00 from the New England Company funds in order to meet the additional burden placed upon the school finances by their farm crop failure and increase in school costs.

Under the circumstances outlined by the Reverend Principal and the Indian Agent, I would recommend approval of the application if the amount applied for is available from the New England Company funds.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa,
December 21, 1943.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the request of the Principal of the St. George's Residential School for payment from New England Company funds.

As you were advised in official letter of the 15th instant, the Department is concerned about the financial situation at this school, as we do not wish any repetition of what happened under the former Principal. The Principal's recent letter which you forwarded bears out the intimation expressed in my letter of the 15th instant.

At the present time there is an amount of approximately $2800.00 in the New England Company account. The company has not yet paid the usual quarterly grant for the quarter ended September 30.

The $2000.00 requested is being forwarded to him, but I trust that either Inspector Coleman or yourself will have an opportunity of discussing the financial situation at this school with the Principal at an early date.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dec. 26, 1943

Commissioner D.M. MacKay,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Sir:

We have just disposed of Christmas Day, with seventy
in bed with the Flu. No nurse, in spite of all our efforts
to cure one. We have no Laundress; and last week had to
really take charge of the laundry work with two or three
to help. At present we have no Engineer. Our man went
with the Flu, and has since had to leave for Vancouver, where
he is very seriously ill. I have had to be up at four and
lock in the morning to look after the heating of this
which at present resembles a hospital. We have no Farm
and so I have had more outside supervising to do. I don't
feel so much like a one man orchestra. Yet, withal,
things are going wondrously well. How long one can stand the
strain I don't know, but conditions cannot get much worse, and the
hope is they will improve.

In reply to your anxious letter of the 21st inst., I beg
your pardon for owing to illness, pressure of work, and shortage of
time in making out my October Financial Statement.
I have been late; and anyone who has the
idea what I and others have been going through since
the end of the term, in the matter of epidemics of
cough and Flu, will recognize some justification
for the statement in your letter that the Department are
not concerned over the financial situation of our school.
It is not at the present time a very pressing concern; but
it is not in debt, if one takes into consideration our
losses. When I took over the administration of this
school there was not only no current surplus, there was a large
In reference to the drop in the Current surplus during the month of October, I have this to say: I received an order to deliver 25 tons of potatoes to Coqualeetza Hospital. In our Spring planting, provision was made for this; and during the month of September, the Farm Manager assured me that we should have plenty of potatoes to fill the order. When I made out the Financial Statement at the end of September, the Farm Manager assured me I could safely include $1000.00 for potatoes which would be delivered at Coqualeetza during the month of October. I included that amount, but the $1000.00 did not materialize. "Counting chickens before they are hatched" you say.

In regard to the salaries being in arrears, I have never been later than the third or fourth day after the end of the month. I used to pay salaries before the end of the month, but so many of the staff held their cheques over, so that I had to carry them as cheques outstanding. I have been issuing the cheques immediately after the end of the month. I did not realize that such procedure meant salaries in arrears. There has been quite a bit of fluctuation in the monthly total salary amounts. I have had considerable difficulty in securing staff workers, who are generally of a unreliable type. They come and stay for a week or so, and leave as soon as they hear of higher wages elsewhere. I have had to raise all salaries twice during the year, and still they are low compared with general rate of salaries, and we are short staffed.

I wish to assure the Department I have tried in every possible way to economize, so that I would not have to ask for an advance on the Quarterly per capita grant allowance. My reason for asking for $2000.00 was so that I might leave the per capita grant allowance intact. I don't suppose there has ever been a time in the history of the school when the New England Copper Company grant was more urgently needed for the general maintenance of the work.

I feel sure the Department realize that the present financial assistance we receive is quite inadequate to meet the needs of present day demands. The only way I know to make that financial assistance suffice is to cut down on the food and clothing for pupils, and to put more boys to work instead of hiring extra labour. But we cannot do these things. At least I would rather leave than do them. Fifty cents per day which we receive as our per capita allowance, seems too small compared with two dollars per day allowed in the hospitals; and yet most of these children require a great deal of care, and certainly much more nourishing foods than they now receive. As charts were received from the Department a short time ago, along with the information regarding the diet these children should be receiving.
are all very fine; and I have no doubt required a great deal of time and expense to produce them, but we cannot carry them out as they should be; simply because our per capita grant allowance is not sufficient to enable us to do so. Our school is not unique in this respect. If a survey were made of all the schools, I have no doubt one would find that very few schools come anywhere near to what the pupils should be having in the way of nourishment. Several times staff members have come here from other schools, and I have enquired of them about the way Indian children have been fed at the schools they have left. Our dietics, if anything, is a little better than the majority of schools, because we have the advantage of tomato juice and fruit. But I would certainly like to see our meals improved.

I assure you, sir, it is not my intention to be disrespectful, but as the Department are inclined to be critical of our financial situation and worried about matters, it is just as well if they hear my views on the subject. I have been in this work for thirty years, and know pretty well what I am talking about.

A careful survey should be made of all the schools. If possible by people who have a thorough and practical knowledge of what is best for the welfare of Residential Schools.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.
St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, February 20, 1945.

Dear Mr. Hives:

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant, an advance of $2,000.00 on the March quarter of the St. George's Residential School is going forward, under separate cover.

From a review of the last two quarters' returns, I am inclined to feel that a part of your evident financial difficulty is due to lack of pupilage. I presume that you have made every possible effort to bring the pupilage to the authorized number, but evidently you are still considerably below that figure. Is there any agent who might be able to assist you to secure additional pupils? If so, let me know, and we will write to him.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend C. F. Hives,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lyttton, B. C.

Rev. C. F. Hives,
Principal

Jan. 9, 1945
Lytton, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Referring to the December Financial Statement, you will note that I have great difficulty in making ends meet. This is partly due to the fact that we have had a number of new pupils crowded on us, who have all had to be outfitted etc. And partly because salaries for staff workers are higher. But I find the proper upkeep and maintenance of the institution is a big expense. It is very necessary that the building and the equipment be kept in repair and in order. We have received very little from Department funds for this purpose; and in consequence our per capita grant allowance is far too heavily drawn on.

I would be very much obliged if you would please place this matter before the Department. If there are New England Company funds available at this time, I would be very much obliged if we could have $2,000.00 for the purpose of replenishing household equipment in the school building, and repairing and replacing implements on the farm.

We have worked extremely hard during the last four years. Personally, I have worked harder than I have ever been called upon to work at anytime in my life; but we have held things together, until now, it looks as though there are brighter times ahead. I would very much like to put our equipment in order. During the last few weeks, I have been able to secure three fine young men from the Services. They will stay if I can make life interesting for them. And they will give good service too, and make life interesting to the boys.

I do try in every possible way to take care of funds entrusted to my care; and I wish to assure you that I shall continue to do so.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hives
Principal.

Mr. A. Strang, Indian Agent, Lytton, B.C.
LYTTON, B.C. January 9, 1946.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,

Feb. 14th, 1946.

Dear Mr. Hives:

Mr. Indian Agent Strang has forwarded your Financial Statement for the month ending January 31st, 1946.

You will recall that in December of 1945 the Department showed some concern over the financial situation at your school, at which time the current surplus over a period of three months dropped from $6775.85 to $4307.05. A review of your recent Financial Statements for the months September, 1945 to January, 1946, inclusive, indicates that the current surplus has dropped from $7524.57 to $4339.43, despite the fact that in January of this year you received a grant of $2000.00 from the New England Company funds.

In anticipation of an enquiry from the Department in this connection it would be appreciated if you would advise if there is any particular reason for the large decrease in the current surplus.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. Macay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Rev. C. F. Hives,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Res. School,
Lytton, B.C.
Dear Major MacKay:

I have just received your letter of the 14th inst. It was my intention to be in Vancouver to see you today; and started away with the car to go to the station to meet the early train this morning; but during the wind storm last night, a large tree had blocked the road and I had to return.

The financial situation is always giving me concern. Sometimes, I feel so concerned over the matter. I would give a lot if I could decently pull out. But, at this time of the year, expenses are much higher than at other times. The fuel, light, clothes, and shoes are items that demand more expense at this time of the year. And, moreover, there is little or nothing coming in excepting the per capita grant allowance. One thing, I can honestly say, we have no large and old debts; and because we have a good attendance of pupils, there should be a substantial amount of earnings for the current quarter.

I expect to be in Vancouver on Monday to try and settle the matter of our domestic hot water supply, and hope to be able to see you at that time.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Commissioner of Indians for B.C.,
Vancouver, B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Dear Mr Hoey:

This is a personal letter to you to ask you if I may ask for two thousand dollars from the New England funds to meet current expenses. Our expenses during the last six months have been extremely high, and I have had great difficulty in making ends meet.

The following is a true idea of how things have been. Our expenditure during the six months ended March 31st amounted to $21,899.92. Our per capita grant allowance amounted to $16,156.24 for that period. We also received $300.00 toward the Manual Instructor's salary, and $2,000.00 from the New England Company funds. The balance we have had to make up ourselves; and during the Wintertime, there is not much coming in from the farm.

I think you know, without my saying, that I have tried in every possible way to take care of funds entrusted to me, as well as keep up a decent standard of living.

Doctor Alderwood was here last week, and seemed to be quite thrilled with what he saw of our life here. And was extremely surprised to know that we had been able to keep ourselves fairly clear of debt. They have an overdraft of over $200,000.00.

Will you kindly let me know about the grant from New England funds.

Kindest regards and best wishes,

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hives,
Principal.

Mr H. A. Hoey,
Director,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Rev. Canon C. F. Hives  
Principal  

Sept. 16, 1946  
Lytton, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Will you kindly ask the Department for an advance on the current quarter's per capita grant earnings to the amount of two thousand dollars.

I regret that I am forced to make this request, but I am experiencing great difficulty in maintaining a proper and normal standard of living, and at the same time keep within the limits of our financial resources or income. The cost of food commodities have advanced considerably; as well as the cost of all manufactured articles, such as clothing, machinery and household wares. Salaries also have had to be increased in order to secure staff workers.

If the amount asked for is to be found in the New England Company funds, I would rather it were taken from that source, and leave the per capita grant intact.

I find the clothing item considerably higher this year; and I have just received a car load of coal, which is also higher than last year.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. A. Strang,  
Indian Agent,  
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Strang:

Owing to the advanced cost of almost everything required in the administration of this institution, including salaries, I find it extremely difficult to meet our financial obligations. I am trying in every possible way to economize, and to take care of things we have, yet, there are certain necessities such as food, clothing, fuel and light, which we must have; and without which, our administration would very quickly be subject to adverse criticism.

I would be very much obliged if you would place this matter before the Department, asking them if there are funds available in the New England Company grant. We require, to meet our clothing, food and fuel account, the sum of $2,000.00, as well as an advance on the current per capita allowance of $2,000.00, in order that I may pay all salaries before the end of the year.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. A. Strang,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.
Rev. Canon C. F. Hives

Dear Colonel Neary:

I am writing you to ask if we have any New England Company funds to our credit. We seem to be always in a state of penury these days. In spite of all the care we try to exercise with things like clothing, shoes, utensils and machinery, they wear out, and need repairing or replenishing. And prices have advanced so in many lines.

At present, we are in need of a conveyance which we use for light delivery, for bringing out bread and such like. We call it the Station wagon. In reality it is a Panel Delivery with seats built in so that we can take care of the transportation of pupils to and from home or hospital. It was bought in 1936, and is not in very good condition; especially for these mountain roads. I would like to replace it this year with another Station Wagon. Next year, I would like to replace the Farm tractor, which is in very poor shape.

If possible, will you kindly send me $2,000.00 from New England Company funds. I assure you, we need it, and the very best care will be taken of it.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hives
Principal.

Colonel B. F. Neary,
Superintendent,
Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Last evening I had to punish seven small boys for going swimming in the river. The Fraser River is quite unsafe here for swimming purposes, and the boys are absolutely forbidden to bathe in it. So far, since I have been here, we have had no drowning accidents; but the Indian people are extremely nervous of their children playing by the river, and I am anxious to avoid any accidents.

We have no swimming pool, and there is none within fifty miles of us. Years ago a dam was built across a ravine, which was then filled with water from the irrigation ditch. This afforded quite a bit of fun for the girls and boys. But it was a very poorly constructed affair and has broken down and become useless.

Recently I received from the Department a New England Company cheque for the amount of one thousand dollars, for the purpose of buying a much needed Station Wagon, to replace the old one we now have. I have been told that I shall not be able to buy one until the latter part of August. In the meantime, the thousand dollars is in a Special account.

Will you please let me know by wire if I may make immediate use of this thousand dollars for the purpose of buying cement, reinforcement and lumber for the immediate construction of a dam, so that we may have a safe and decent swimming pool for our girls and boys. And in the event of this sanction from you, may we have a similar amount during the month of August for the purpose of buying the Station Wagon.

Yours faithfully,

Rev. Canon C. F. Hives
Principal

Colonel B. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 13th, 1947.

Dear Mr. Hives:

We have your letter of the 6th instant in which you suggest that the $1,000 forwarded to you for the purchase of a station wagon be used to provide a swimming pool.

While it is realized from your letter that a swimming pool at the St. George's School is desirable, at the same time I regret that we cannot authorize the use of the funds that you have already received for that particular purpose.

The New England Company grant is exhausted at the present time and what is received during the next two or three quarters will be required for urgent repairs suggested by the officer of the Surveys and Engineering Branch who recently visited your school.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. C.F. Hives,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Res. School,
Lytton, B.C.

After I have made out the Salary cheques for this current month, our finances will be at a pretty low ebb, and insufficient to pay the December salaries or meet current expenses.

Will you please ask the Department for an advance of $3,000.00 on the Oct-Dec. quarterly allowance.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. A. Strang,  
Indian Agent,  
Lytton, B.C.

Forwarded herewith is the usual financial statement submitted by the Reverend Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School, for the month of January, 1948, accompanied by a letter from the above Principal.

In view of the seriousness of the financial situation of the school I would respectfully recommend that the Principal's request for assistance receive all possible Departmental consideration.

A. Strang,
Indian Agent.
Rev. Canon C. F. Hives  
Principal

Feb. 14, 1948  
Lytton, B. C.

Dear Sir:

The enclosed Monthly Financial Statement, will, I feel sure cause the Department some concern, in anticipation of which, I am writing you, with the request that you will give your best consideration to my letter, and make whatever comments you think best before sending it on to the Department in Vancouver and from there to Ottawa.

Until this present month, I have taken quite a bit of pride in sending to you my Financial Statement, but you will notice, I am sure that the enclosed will reveal the fact that we are slipping financially. And that, unless we can receive special financial help we shall be in debt. As indeed we now are.

During the six and a half years that I have been in charge of St. George's School, I have paid a total of $10.65 to the bank for overdraft interest. I have always paid my staff before the end of the month, so that their salaries have always been shown on the current month. I have tried not to draw on the Quarterly allowance until the last month of the quarter. Unless we can secure financial help other than the current quarter's allowance, I shall have to do so this month.

Taking into consideration that this is always the most expensive period of the year, on account of fuel, light and lack of farm produce, there are still other reasons why we are having such great difficulty in financing our school business. There are many more demands made on our financial resources these days than were ever made before. Each time a new idea leaves the Ottawa office, new demands are made on our financial resources. Diet sheets, posters, full time classroom hours for all pupils; all these mean more financial commitments. We receive appetizing diet posters, with instructions to explain what balanced diet meant. The amount of milk and butter and fish and fruit juices that should be taken so many times a day. They are all very well, and, I have no doubt they are all very necessary in the building up of a strong healthy body. But common-sense should tell us that to comply with all that advice it is absolutely impossible to do it on 70 cents per capita per day, and take care of all
expenses that come from increased salaries, increased prices on foods, clothing, fuel etc., etc. I have good reasons for saying that it cannot be done.

We read letters and articles in the newspaper about the poor attention Indian pupils are receiving in the Residential schools. Many of these articles and letters are written by well meaning people. But I don't suppose anyone of them realize that in order to treat Indian pupils in residential schools the same way as children of well-to-do parents would be treated in a private residential school, the per capita allowance would have to be doubled twice and more. And I don't suppose for one minute the rate payer would stand for it.

But, I do feel sure that there is a happy medium that could be reached. Owing to the advanced cost of living, the per capita allowance we now receive is not sufficient to meet the necessary expenses which we must incur.

To tide us over until the end of the present quarter, when prices may possibly take a dip down, we should have three thousand dollars exclusive of the current per capita allowance. We must have two thousand dollars in order to pay our debts. If that amount is to be found in the New England Company funds, I shall be exceedingly grateful for it, and it will take a great load off my mind. If it is not to be found in New England Company funds, I want you to know that we shall not be able to meet our obligations when they come due.

It has taken some years to bring this school back to a position of respectability and honour in this community and with the business houses. I would like, if at all possible, to retain that position.

Enclosed, you will find attached to the Financial Statement, a comparison of salaries and prices etc. between the years 1941 and 1947. These prices are conservative, and I have no doubt the Department are fully aware of them.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. A. Strang,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Strang's letter of February 13th and enclosures referred to therein regarding the financial situation at St. George's Indian Residential School.

You will note that the current surplus during the period December 31st, 1947 to January 31st, 1948, decreased from $5,068.78 to $1,180.73 and that the Rev. Principal anticipates a deficit of $3000 before the end of the present quarter unless increased financial assistance is secured from the New England Company funds or elsewhere.

I have reason to believe the financial difficulties being encountered by St. George's School at this time are not in any way greater than the difficulties being encountered by other residential schools in British Columbia and have no doubt that the Department is being pressed for increased per capita and other grants to meet the deficits. Presumably consideration is being given to methods of meeting residential school financial problems but in the meantime if there are funds available from the New England Company a special grant would be of considerable assistance to St. George's School.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
AIR MAIL

February 26, 1948.

Dear Canon Hives:

Indian Commissioner Arneil has forwarded to the Department your letter of February 14, 1948, in connection with the financial situation at the St. George's Indian Residential School.

Yesterday we were advised that approval had been given for an increase of $17% in the per capita allowance of each residential school, effective from October 1st, 1947. In the case of the St. George's Residential School this will mean an extra payment on the December quarter of $1,736.63. Cheque for this amount will go forward in the near future. In addition, we will forward you a cheque for $1,000.00 from New England Company funds. You will recall that we forwarded you $800.00 from the New England Company funds about the end of November last.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard N. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Rev. Canon C.F. Hives,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Res. School,
Lytton, B.C.
c/o to Mr. Arneil.

Memorandum:

Dear Sir:

Our financial situation is becoming more and more acute. At this time of the year, there seem to be so many expenses and obligations to meet in the way of clothes, fuel and light. Almost everything has trebled in price during the last few years, and we are no longer able to meet our financial obligations with the revenue at present coming to us. In spite of the fact that we do try, as much as possible, from the produce of our lands to help sustain ourselves.

Will you please ask the Department for an advance from the current quarterly per capita grant allowance to the amount of four thousand dollars. I must pay salaries and meet other expenses, but at the present time we have no funds with which to do this.

An early reply will be very much appreciated.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. A. Strang,
Superintendent, Lytton Agency,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

The financial cares of this school are weighing very heavily. I don't know how long I can stand it, but unless some help comes in the near future, I am afraid something will break. I hate to bring myself into the matter, but the doctor tells me that my condition is not good, and I am losing too much sleep and running too high a blood pressure. I assure you it is not caused from high living.

I know it is terribly difficult for you, but surely the matter of adequate financial support for the proper and decent administration of this and other schools should be of paramount importance to the Government of Canada.

As far as outward appearances go, people think we are in wonderful shape. We have a lovely school, lovely buildings, fine lot of children and a fairly efficient and fairly well-paid staff. And we are looked upon with not a little envy by the other schools. And yet, those other schools receive far more than we do. They receive all girls' clothing from the W.A., while we have to buy every bit of ours. They receive all boys' clothing, up to twelve years of age. And they receive all bedding for the whole school from W.A.

I don't think it is possible to finance this school on a per capita grant allowance of $257.00 per annum, paying a decent living wage to the staff, and giving decent meals to the pupils. We have had a long hard Winter. Three months of cold weather, with two days of mild weather. You can imagine how serious has been the matter of fuel expenses. Yet I have received no complaint from any member of my staff concerning cold rooms, and we have had no freeze-ups. Last night, the middle of February, it was below zero. Seven years ago I bought coal for $1.10 per ton, f.o.b. the mines. For the same coal I have to pay $4.65 f.o.b. the mines, and you know how freight rates have advanced. Everything else has advanced in like proportion. But you know all this, and I am sure you must become weary of hearing it.

I don't want to leave this place, and I feel that I should not pass out at my age. And I would like to feel that this work will continue to prosper, if I should
have to move on.

The hope of a fall in prices for everything we have to buy, seems to have been a matter of wishful thinking. The only thing that I know of that has not advanced during the last seven years is my own salary, which has to remain the same because to increase it would be depriving an Indian child of some of the little it now has.

I do not know if we have anything in New England Company funds; but if there is anything, I would greatly appreciate receiving it right now. But, in any case, I am of the opinion that we must either receive more financial support from the Dominion Government for the proper and decent administration of this and other schools; or that this and other schools should be closed, and the children sent home to be the care and responsibility of their parents.

You will, I know forgive me for writing you this way. I am not able to run into your office and give you the "woiks" as I used to do. But you are our best hope in this time of trouble; and you do know conditions, probably better than any other man who has preceded you in office you now occupy. And I also know, from past associations with you, that you will do your part in alleviating this difficult situation.

With kindest regards and every good wish.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
23rd February, 1949.

Memorandum:

MAJOR MACKAY

Re: Canon Hives' letter
of 12th February, 1949

At the present time there is a balance of $1,603.80 in the New England Company account, and I recommend that we send Canon Hives $1,500.00 of this amount.

The promise of the New England Company was that they would make a payment of £1000 a year towards this school. That amount is approximately $5,000.00. However, due to restrictions on exporting funds from England at the present time, the amount which we actually receive is slightly over $3,000.00 a year. During the calendar year 1948, Canon Hives received $3,000.00 from the New England Company funds.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

February 26, 1949.

Dear Canon Hives:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 12th, in which you refer to the difficulties you are experiencing in operating the school in a satisfactory way on the per capita grant being paid at the present time.

I may say that the department is examining the auditors' reports on our residential schools as they come to hand. These reports present a fairly accurate picture of the situation and provide information on which representations for revision of rates may be made.

The cost of operating our residential schools is a subject that is constantly under review and it is hoped that, as a result of the information supplied by the auditors, it will be possible to make the adjustments indicated.

At this date, the balance in the New England Company account stands at $1,608.80. Of this amount the sum of $1,500.00 is being forwarded and should reach you within the next few days.

I was sorry to note from your letter that you were not feeling up to the mark. I trust that this will find you restored in health and things generally going well with you.

With kind personal regards,

Rev. Canon C.F. Hives,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Residential School,
LYTTON, British Columbia.

Yours faithfully,

Director.

Dear Mr Strang:

Will you please apply to the Department for an advance cheque on the present quarter per capita grant allowance, to the amount of four thousand dollars.

Our current expenses have been very heavy. We have had to burn very much more fuel during the Winter months than ever before. And the price of fuel is three times higher than previous years. Our electric light bill has been running over two hundred dollars a month, and there seems to be no decrease in the price of other commodities.

I am hoping that the Spring may bring some release. Certainly the fuel and light bills will not be so heavy.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. A. Strang,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Lytton, B.C.

Mr. [Signature]

St. George's School - Financial Statements:

These need various changes in order to present a true picture of the institution's standing at the end of any month.

Items are not being charged against the month to which they apply. E.g., salaries are doubled in January as compared with July. Food for July (1) costs three hundred times as much as June. There is no apparent consumption of fuel or light in October.

The method of entering deficits and cash book balances, outstanding cheques and accounts payable, per capita grant due rather than "earned", makes any month's figures of less than true significance.

There must be some less mystifying analysis possible.

C.A.T. Clark
1/4/44
Dear Mr Phelan:

I was very glad indeed to get your letter yesterday, calling for Financial Statements, which I herewith enclose. In spite of the fact that the one ending Feb. 28th., is not a very encouraging one, I am rather proud of our shewing; for we have had a very very difficult time making ends meet. I don't think there is much reason for me to explain why, for you would get only a repetition of what you have heard from every other quarter. However, we are over the worst of it, I hope, and next quarter should enable us to pick up a little.

But not only are prices for all commodities abnormally high, we also have to try and satisfy the new demands that are being made. I mean, for instance, we get a write-up from Dept. of National Health, every once in awhile, telling us what we are to feed our pupils. We cannot possibly comply with their requests under the present per capita allowance without going into debt. We do our best, and in order to produce the milk required, we have to buy feed for the cows; and you will note that the farm expenses come high. Then there is the matter of classroom. The inspectors come along, and their one idea is academic training. If they had their way about it, the girls and boys would be attending school full time, and because work outside of the classroom makes the pupils tired in the classroom, we should have an army of servants to do the work in the different and various departments. They should know we are not able to afford this, but they don't stop to consider. I try to be as efficient as possible and I believe, from what the inspector says, we have one of the best, if not the best, teaching set-up in the province.

What I am trying to get over to you is that with each demand comes extra expense, and on the top is the abnormal cost of living.

Kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal

Mr. Phillip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
St. George's Indian Residential School
LYTTON, B.C.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Mr Phelan:

Enclosed please find March and April Financial Statements. I don't know if we shall gradually evolve from the mire or not, but it is hard, slow work. The future does not loom up very bright, unless some definite policy is made by experts in this particular kind of education and training, and financial assistance given adequate to meet the policy and situation.

I am working harder now than I have ever worked in all the years I have been engaged in this work.

This matter of education and academic training for Indian children requires more than just the ideas of some young educationist. School inspectors come around, and of course, they specialize in classroom education. They want all boys and girls to attend school full time, if at all possible. That is their stand. Alright from their standpoint, and they have every right "sell their goods!" But there is the danger of making educated bums of the boys and girls, and if they all go to school all the time, we should engage more servants. We have not the money to do so, and people, these days, are afraid of being benevolent, and require high wages. Today, we have one boy out of the classroom in the morning to help with the work on the farm.

The auditor comes around, and he asks me who does my office work. I tell him, and he says I have no business to be doing office work as well as administering. I could not afford a secretary. Just as soon as I have written this, I shall have to don a pair of dirty old overalls and go either fencing or hoeing.

Things seem to pile up these days, and they don't make a lovely pile either. But, I suppose the only thing is to plug along to the bitter end, which I hope may be, at least, peaceful, when it does come.

Kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. P. Phelan,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
May 27th, 1949.

Rev. Canon C.F. Hives,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Res. School,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Canon Hives:

We have your letter of the 13th instant enclosing your financial statement for the months of March and April, 1949.

Everyone connected with Indian Affairs seem to be busy these days, and we note from your letter that you are no exception to the rule. If it is not asking too much, we would appreciate having the financial statement as soon as possible after the end of each month.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
Rev. Canon C. F. Hives  
Principal

May 28, 1949  
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Sir:

Will you kindly send me a cheque to the amount of five thousand dollars as part of the current quarter's per capita grant allowance.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.
Province of BRITISH COLUMBIA.

Dear Mr Phelan:

The quarterly cheque has not yet arrived, and I am getting anxious about it, for fear it has gone astray. I have quite a lot of bills to pay, and an overdraft at the bank.

I find, as others no doubt do, that it is almost impossible to make ends meet these days, and I do sincerely hope that a substantial increase in the per capita allowance is soon to be realized.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6463, file 888-3, part 4)
November 16, 1949.

Rev. Canon C.F. Hives,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Canon Hives:

We have your letter of the 11th instant regarding payment of the September Quarter Per Capita Allowance for St. George's Indian Residential School.

I am advised by the Treasury Branch that a cheque for $7,503.74 was mailed to you on November 8th and should have reached you by this time. As you are aware we had previously forwarded you an advance of $5,000.00 on the September Quarter earnings. We are still hopeful that there will be some increase in per capita grants and we expect to write you in this regard within the next two or three weeks.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

PP/MMcN
Dear Mr Phelan:

Many thanks for your letter of the 16th, and for the hopeful news that we can expect an increase in the Grant Allowance in the near future; also I hope a retroactive cheque.

At the present time we are cut off from the rest of the world. So the radio says, and also the fact that we cannot get anywhere by road or rail, on account of landslides and washed-out bridges. We have not suffered, excepting that when the builders provided rain disposal for the roofs of our building, they did not figure on the torrential rains of last Saturday, when we were bailing water out of the basement during the best part of the night.

Will you kindly send an advance cheque on the current quarter to the amount of $5,000.00. I must pay salaries, and I must try and keep ahead of some of the debts. It is a worrying business, but your letter again revived some hopes of better things ahead.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hives
Principal

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief Education Division,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

CANADA
Dear Mr Phelan:

Enclosed herewith, please find Financial Statements of the months May to November inclusive.

I am still hoping that better days are ahead of us. It has been a very worrying time keeping things at a fairly even keel, and you will notice that our financial obligations are quite heavy at the end of November. In future the Financial Statement will be on time each month, as I have, since receiving your letter with the good news of an increase in the Allowance, engaged a secretary. Since I have been here, I have done all the office work myself, and tried also to give as much of my time as possible to the farm activities. Had it not been for our farm produce, both in regard to what we consume and what we have been able to dispose of, we would have been in poor shape.

Comparing salaries of today with those of 1942, you will notice that I have had to increase them. All have been increased considerably, my own excepted. It has remained the same throughout.

I am still waiting patiently or otherwise for that promised large cheque.

Thanks very much for your kindly wishes. Please accept the same from me to you and yours. At present we are really snowed under four feet of snow, and the going is pretty tough.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. Philip Phelan
Chief, Education Division,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Jan. 21, 1950  
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Thanks for your letter of the 13th inst. We received the cheque on that day also; so I felt that Friday the 13th was not a day to be despised. I assure you it was a most welcome help, and I would like to say how much I appreciate it. I have no doubt you had your share in bringing about the small increase. You and I have been in this business a long time. In fact, we might almost be classed as "old-timers!" I think, therefore, you will know that an appreciation from me is something real and sincere.

We are having quite a terrible time of it right now, for we have over five feet of snow, and it looks like more to follow. I hope there will not be very much more, for we are having a very difficult time getting out of this hole, and bringing in provisions and fuel. Even the very dim recollections you may have of this place will give you a picture of what we are having to go through down in this hole with all this snow. At present, I am a little worried about six or seven children who started from Hazelton two days ago on the C.N.R. I don't know when they will arrive, for trains are all at a stand-still in B.C. Hazelton is a long way off. I mean, it takes a long time to make the trip, and it is quite expensive. If they go by way of Prince Rupert, it takes about four days; and the way by C.N.R. is almost three days. We do need a residential school in that vicinity in the worst way.

Kindest regards,

Yours sincerely.

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
St. George's Indian Residential School
LYTTON, B.C.

DEPARTMENT OF CITIZENSHIP & IMMIGRATION
Indian Affairs Branch

Ottawa, March 16th, 1950.

TO: Principals of
Indian Residential Schools

Quarterly Return
Quarter Ending March 31st, 1950.

It has been impressed on the Principals of
Residential Schools that the quarterly return should be
prepared at the end of each quarter and forwarded promptly
to the Department through the office of your Superintendent.

However, many Principals evidently delay
preparation of the return, as many of the returns do not
reach the Indian Affairs Branch until 4 or 5 weeks following
the end of the quarter, and in several instances, the
Branch has found it necessary to write Principals regarding
a delayed return.

In future, we expect that each and every Principal
will forward the quarterly return immediately following
the close of the quarter.

This year we are particularly anxious to have
the March quarter return reach us promptly, and therefore,
we will expect this return to reach Ottawa not later than
April 15th, 1950.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Dear Mr Phelan:

Our dormitories are badly in need of replenishment of bedding. I had hoped that this would have been attended to before, but we have never had the funds. And although a kind of a half-promise has been made several times, by the Department, to try and procure some for us from War Assets, we have, so far never received any.

I would also like to see something done to improve conditions in staff rooms.

Will you kindly see if there is a thousand dollars available in the New England Company funds which could be used for the purpose mentioned above.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Phillip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

G.A. Roedde, Ltd.
October 20th 1950.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Before Canon Hives left here on his trip to England, he informed me that he would be stopping at Ottawa on the way, and would ask the Department to send a cheque to the Bank for $5,000.00 on the current quarter to meet expenses and pay salaries.

Although I had not heard from the Bank that a cheque had been received, I paid the September salaries and also, on October 15th, the bills which Canon Hives requested me to pay, but yesterday the Bank informed me that the school has now an overdraft of $5,076.05.

In the recent Financial Statement sent to the Department ending September 30th, the per capita grant due was $8,770.00

The Bank has asked that no further cheques be issued until they receive a cheque from the Department, and as I shall soon have to issue the salary cheques again, would you kindly send a cheque to the Bank at Ashcroft to straighten this matter out.

Yours faithfully,

Acting Principal.
October 24, 1950.

Mr. R.F. Purvis,
Acting Principal,
St. George's Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Purvis:

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant, Cheque 32524 in an amount of $8,788.90, representing the balance of the per capita allowance for the quarter ended September 30th, was mailed from here on October 20th.

It is hoped that the cheque has reached you by this time.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

CANADA
26, Bloomsbury Square,
London, W.C.

9th December 1920

Dear Sirs,

We have instructed our Bankers to transmit to you the sum of £812.10/- for St. George's School, Lytton. This represents the normal grant of £750 plus an extraordinary grant of £250 which the Company wish to be devoted towards the cost of a new truck which they understand is urgently required by the School. Canon Hives, the Principal of the School, visited England this Autumn, and the Company understood from him that his existing truck was worn out and that help was urgently needed to enable a new one to be secured. Owing to Exchange limitations, the Company are unable to provide this extraordinary grant.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Governor.

The Superintendent of Welfare & Training,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Canon Hives:

We have received the following letter from the New England Company:

"We have instructed our Bankers to transmit to you the sum of £812.10/- for St. George's School, Lytton. This represents the normal grant of £750 plus an extraordinary grant of £250 which the company wish to be devoted towards the cost of a new truck which they understand is urgently required by the School. The above letter is not exactly clear, but in any case the amount we received is $2,401.95 (£812.10/- at the rate of $2.95 5/8). As this amount was evidently paid for a special purpose, we are requesting the Treasury to forward you a cheque immediately.

CANADA
Dear Mr Phelan:

I have just recently received a letter from Sir Arthur Cochrane, Governor of New England Company, in which he tells me that he has made arrangements with their bank to send over the sum of eight hundred and twelve pounds ten shilling. That amount with what is already there will almost pay for the truck I have arranged to purchase. Our old truck has gone to pieces so badly, it is now but a bill of expense keeping it running. And it is so important our having a truck. The one I have arranged to buy is an International, and a good size. The cost is a little over three thousand dollars, complete with body and other equipment.

I would be very much obliged if you would send to me all we can have from the New England Company fund, so that I may pay for the truck as soon as it is delivered. I will send to you the receipted bill for the truck, or at least a copy of same.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Educational Division,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

CANADA
Dear Mr Phelan:

The enclosed Monthly Financial Statement is the most unsatisfactory one I have sent in during the last ten long years. I have tried in every way to keep above the thin red line, but the steady climb of prices is too much for the slim revenue we receive. On account of our water failure of last year, our crops were likewise a failure. I am hoping that the situation on that respect will be improved this year.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Training,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Mr Phelan:

Will you please let me know if we have sufficient money in the fund which New England Company has sent over to replace our School car. I received a letter from Sir Arthur Cochrane last week, in which he said New England Company were increasing the amount of their donation to us from 750 pounds to 1125 pounds. The school car has come to the stage where it will now be a bill of expense. As you are well aware, this part of the country, with its wicked mountain roads is not only very hard on a car, but, unless a car is in first rate shape, driving becomes hazardous. A short time ago, I was driving to Lilloet on important school business, and one of the front wheels came off. Luckily it was on the side furthest away from the four or five hundred foot drop, and so I just ran into the bank. Also, I was by myself at the time.

I would require $1500.00 to make the replacement on a Chevrolet car, and I would like to have it during the month of July.

I would be very much obliged if you would let me know as soon as possible if this amount would be available at that time.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Rev. Canon C.F. Hives,

St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Canon Hives:

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, we have recently received from the New England Company an amount of $834.60. This represents a payment of £281.5 converted at 2.965.

In addition, there is $431.61 remaining in the account from last year.

I am requesting the Treasury to forward you a cheque for $1,200.00

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education

Sir,

I herewith beg to enclose certificate in favor of William M. Orr for work done on the erection of the St. George's Indian Industrial School barn.

I have examined the work and find the frame of the barn all erected and that he has expended the amount certified to in the certificate, so the voucher is made out for 90% of the amount stated.

Sir,

HG/MD
Ottawa, Nov. 20, 1923.

Sir:

Replying to your telegram of the 24th instant regarding the extension by this Department of the insurance policy on the new barn at St. George's Industrial School at Lytton, I beg to inform you that this building should be insured by the contractor as mentioned in the "GENERAL CONDITIONS" of the specification, until the building is completed and accepted.

It is not the custom of this Department to carry insurance policies on any of its buildings.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Ass't Deputy & Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.
Sir,

Nor having heard anything further about the proposed water system for the St. George's Industrial School barn, and future new school, I wish that the Department would give this their immediate attention as very soon the ground will be freezing up, and we will be stuck, and be without water in the barn all winter.

Your obediently,

(H. Graham)

Indian Agent.

R. G. Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

HG/MD
Sir,

I beg to confirm follow nightlettergram:

"Does Department intend carry policy on St. George's School new barn, if so, recommend taking three years' policy, and contract to pay pro rata whilst building is under construction. Reply." (Signed) H. Graham, sent you in regard to the insurance on St. George's School new barn. According to the specifications of the contractor, he had to insure the barn during construction, and on getting rates, it was found very much cheaper to take out a three year policy instead of taking a short one, the contractor to pay his portion pro rata whilst the barn is under construction.

Trusting the Department have wired me instructions,

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

We acknowledge receipt of your letter containing instructions for wiring The St Georges School at Lytton, B.C.

Re Generating Equipment:

We note you wish to use the gas engine installed at the Laundry, as it will require a 3 Kilowatt generator for this installation which will require the full 6 H.P. of this engine to drive it. This leaves no margin for use in the Laundry and makes it impossible to operate both together.

This being the case it will be necessary to run the engine after the Laundry work is done and well into the night to supply necessary lighting and charge up the batteries, also changing belts every time, and will not be automatic in operation, this last is important in an isolated plant where there is not expert operators. It will also be necessary to enlarge the Building for generator and storage batteries and which will have to be practically Frost proof. This building will cost approximately between two and three hundred dollars.

In view of these facts the writer is of the opinion that an Independent Generating Set might be considered. I have
discussed this matter with Mr Graham & The Principle who are in favour of an independent set and advised me to submit comparative cost to you for consideration. Further such a set could be installed in the basement of the School only a foundation being needed.

CANADA
Sir,

On inspecting the new barn at St. George's School this morning, I noticed that there are supposed to be braces every eight feet from the floor to the plate. Now these will take away a lot of space from the loft, besides the weight of the hay will come onto them and thus throw the weight onto the sill to which these are attached. Would it not be possible to leave these out altogether, as the way the roof is braced now, there can be no movement whatever? These braces will no doubt take up a lot of space in the barn besides making it very inconvenient to work along the edge.

I also notice that the gable ends have no bracing to prevent them bulging. At the end that the hay is taken in at, hay will bump it and will certainly make it bulge, and the far end when filling the barn, hay will roll against this gable, and will certainly make it bulge without strengthening timbers right across both gable ends.

There was no door allowed in the event of requiring to take any hay out of the loft. There is only one high door at which hay is taken by the derrick fork, so I have had a door put in underneath this one at the floor level.

Everything is going very satisfactorily, and if the steel stanchions, etc., turn up in time, I hope we will be able to occupy it by Christmas.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

R.G. Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Dept. of Ind. Affairs,
Ottawa.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

CANADA

Ottawa, Dec. 5, 1933.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

In connection with the new barn that is being built for the St. Joseph's Indian School at Lytton it will be necessary to provide water at the barn. In erecting this barn the Indian Agent took into consideration the possibility of building a new school in the near future, and the barn is located at a point where there is an ideal site for the building of a new school. This location is approximately a half mile from the old school building.

One of the big difficulties at the present school building is the water supply, and in choosing the new site care was taken to see that a good supply of water could be obtained. At a distance of 2400 feet behind the barn and at an elevation of approximately 175 feet there is an excellent spring, which has been running for many years both winter and summer. This spring will provide all the water that is required for the farm and school on a gravity system. When the new school is built it will be necessary to build a small tank at the source of supply, but for the present I am of the opinion that it is not necessary to clean out the spring and place a large barrel in order to supply water to the barn. It will be necessary to run a four inch pipe from the spring to the barn, a distance of 2400 feet. This pipe will be large enough to be used later if a new school is built to supply it with water.

The cost of this work will be approximately $900.00 and I beg to recommend that the contractor for the barn be authorized to proceed with the installation on a proven cost plus ten percent basis. The new barn is nearing completion and the water supply system should be installed as soon as possible before the ground freezes too hard.

[Signature]
