When I was at Lytton School the Reverend Principal and the Indian Agent pointed out to me the necessity of providing immediately a small dairy building for use in connection with the barn now being erected.

I advised them that it would be impossible for the Department this year to erect any further buildings, but I explained to the Reverend Principal that if he was willing to perform the necessary labour the Department might consider allowing for the materials required. I asked him to let me have an estimate of the cost of the materials. I have today received a letter from the Indian Agent in which he states that all of the materials required will cost approximately $200.00. This will provide for a building 16 x 18 feet and will meet their requirements. The principal will, of course, supply all the labour required in the erection of the building.

As it is necessary that they have this building to carry on their work I beg to recommend that the Indian Agent be authorized to purchase the necessary materials.

Architect.
Sir,

We have been waiting patiently to hear from you since you left, in regard to the installing of the water system for the new barn at St. George's School.

I wrote you so that you would get the letter on your return to Ottawa, about December 1st, but have had no reply.

I now beg to confirm the following night-telegram just sent you.

"Kindly advise me what arrangements have been made about putting in water to the new barn at St. George's School. Frost will soon make it difficult to dig trench, and it is essential to have water at the barn. Wire instructions."

As you can realize if this trench is not dug before the frost gets in too deep, it will cost considerably more. The barn should be ready for use by the new year, and it is very essential that there should be water laid on for the use of the stock.

I trust that you have wired me before you receive this.

Yours truly,

(H. Graham)

R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Dept. of Ind. Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I beg to confirm telegram sent you as follows:

"Can you undertake wiring Lytton School on cost plus ten percent basis wire me Vancouver Hotel",

and your reply:

"Will take job at Lytton on terms stated".

and my wire to you,

"Proceed to Lytton School and consult with Indian Agent Graham re wiring Lytton School"
Letter following addressed to Lytton care of Graham".

It is proposed to wire the school in an exposed conduit system of wiring, and supplying only the lights absolutely necessary to light the building. All of the lights to be installed to be operated by drop-lights and no switches. There is a present located in the laundry gasoline engine which it is proposed to use for operating the dynamo. This dynamo should be 110 volt and capable of supplying current to 75% of all lights installed. It will also be necessary to install a storage battery 56 cells capable of supplying light to 75% of the lights for 8 hours with generator not running, the battery to be manufactured by the Hart Battery Manufacturing Company. There also will be required the regular switch-board. You will notice that a portion of this building is already wired for electric lights, this wiring, however, was installed some time ago and I do not think is in a safe condition - new conduit wiring should therefore be run throughout the building.
I have also to ask that you supply and install the necessary wiring to connect up with the new barn now being erected. The Reverend Principal of the school will supply and erect the necessary pole line.

All of this work is to be carried out in accordance with the rules and regulations covering such work in the Province of British Columbia and also to the full and entire satisfaction of the Indian Agent.

All accounts for the work should be submitted in duplicate to Indian Agent Graham who will forward them to the Department.

Any further information you desire regarding this work please communicate with me, The Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Yours very truly,

Architect for
The Department of Indian Affairs,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,

Lytton, B.C., January 25th, 1924.

Mr. H. Graham,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Graham:

Just a line to remind you to notify the Dept. of our farm needs. The truck which I applied for last Autumn, we hope to receive ere the harvesting begins next fall. As you know we are in good shape for a bumper production this year and a truck would greatly aid transportation. The manure spreader asked for is highly necessary especially so for this irrigated land as the machine pulverizes or breaks it up so that no straw is apt to gather in the ditches, and so block up the small streams which run over the land.

I asked for a span of horses, but with a colt ready to break, we can, I hope, fit out a light team, which will be able to be used for lighter work, cross harrowing, mowing, raking, &c., and make the heavier team unnecessary for the time being, if we can get the truck.

It is my desire herewith to thank the Department for so liberally coming to our assistance this past year in building us a barn which is now the greatest asset we are in possession of, and also the lights in the school which take away the jeopardy of coal oil lamps, and give such a brilliant light in comparison. We are truly grateful for these needed acquisitions.

Again thanking you and hoping you will see fit to endorse the above needs asked for.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
I regret to have to report the very great inconvenience at St. George's Indian Industrial School, this winter, owing to the lack of domestic water. This matter, I think, will be dealt with in Mr. School Inspector Caffin's report.

Some two and a half years ago, we put in a wooden pipe for domestic water to the spring from which the supply was obtained. This worked very well until last summer when, owing to the very dry summer the spring dried up, practically altogether, and during the summer the school was relying upon irrigation water. In the fall the spring supplied just about sufficient water, but as soon as the very cold weather came, everything froze up, and for the last month the school has practically been without water, except for odd days. At one time there was none at all and every atom of water used in the school had to be hauled a considerable distance in barrels. The staff has worked practically day and night trying to thaw out and get what little water they can down.

At the present time there is an outbreak of measles in the school, and when I was there yesterday, they had no water for toilets or other purposes. During the remainder of this winter they will just have to carry on as they are doing today, and in the spring try to collect every spring available and live in hope that the original spring may come back to its own after the spring freshets, otherwise some other source of water supply will have to be found for the coming winter.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I herewith beg to enclose the 4th certificate in favor of William M. Orr, contractor for the barn at St. George's Indian Industrial School, which has been completed and is now in use.

I have already reported to you making an inspection of this barn with Mr. School Inspector Cairns and the principal, and everything was found quite satisfactory.

You will notice that there is a second lot of extras, amounting to $467.06. A separate account for these is attached. You authorized certain of them yourself when here, which authority you promised to send back to me in writing when you returned to Ottawa, but which has not arrived yet—although I wrote sometime ago for this, viz.—the high cement mangers, the extra iron posts and single stalls for horses, extra light switches and twenty-six galvanized window shields. The loft door I authorized, and advised you about at the time, as there was no means of getting hay out of the loft at any time that it might be required. The extra strengthening of the gable ends, and putting the silo down to the depth of the cellar, were both authorized by departmental letters.

I am enclosing three photographs of the completed barn, which I thought might be of interest to you.

I am also enclosing a written agreement signed by Mr. Orr, in which he is to be responsible for keeping the barn in entire repair for one year, as called for by the specifications.

Trusting that you will find everything in order,

Ottawa, Feb. 12, 1924.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, enclosing certificate in duplicate in payment of the contract for work done at the St. George's Indian Industrial school.

As you neglected to sign these certificates I am returning them herewith, and would ask that you please sign them and forward them to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.
Sir,

I have departmental letter dated February 1st, in reply to mine of the 25th ult., when I reported the unsatisfactory condition of the domestic water supply at St. George's Industrial School.

I might say that my reason for reporting this was in the event of something having to be done at a later date, the Department would then be conversant with the conditions.

I have talked the matter over with the principal, and although there is no shortage of water at the present time, owing to the thaw we have lately experienced, yet we have no assurance that the spring that originally supplied this school, and which dried up like many others in the district, last summer, will ever come back. We will connect up every available source of supply in the hope that these may continue to run next winter. During the summer we are able to turn in the irrigation ditch, which of course gives us an ample supply, but of very inferior dirty water.

If the springs do not come back to normal, the only solution that we can see will be the installation of a pump system, which will be quite expensive, owing to the distance that the water will have to be pumped.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Russell T. Perrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

HG/MD
Sir,

I have departmental letter dated February 7th, advising me that the Deputy Superintendent General has directed that a favorable consideration be given towards supplying the Lytton Indian Industrial School a suitable truck, and he suggests that a Ford truck be supplied, if it be adequate.

In reply I beg to state that I have shown this letter to the principal and am now enclosing a letter from him on the subject.

I might also add that I have had considerable experience in what trucks can do in this district. There have been Ford trucks used here and everyone of them has been discarded or turned in for heavier trucks, as they found they were not at all suitable, they had not the power and only being one ton capacity, they become really far more expensive to operate than a larger truck of greater power and larger capacity. With the hills that we have to negotiate here I feel sure that a Ford truck would be too expensive and too much time would be wasted in hauling such a small load for the distance that we have to travel.

For instance, this coming season, if all goes well, we hope to have a large quantity of hay to sell from Lot 47, which is 6½ miles from town, with a 3½ mile hill to traverse, so unless we had a large truck, it would be very slow work hauling out with a one ton truck. Then again there is the heavy hauling of firewood, which could hardly be done with a light truck.

Thanking the Department for their kind consideration of this matter, and trusting that they will favorably consider a heavier and stronger make than a Ford,

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6464, file 888-5, part 1)
S. GEORGE'S INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL FOR INDIAN BOYS AND GIRLS

Supported by the New England Company. (The oldest English Missionary Society, founded 1649)

Lytton, B.C., February 13th, 1924.

Mr. H. Graham,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Graham:

Re Purchase of Truck.

You indeed brought us good news when you conveyed to us the word that the Department had allowed you a grant with which to purchase a truck for the school.

A truck will be of untold advantage to us, in time and energy. While we appreciate all the Department has lately done for us and feel that no suggestion on our part should be made on what kind of a truck we should have, yet may we be allowed to say, that owing to the nature of these mountain roads, a Ford truck would not be the most economical with so much heavy up-hill work. It would not stand up under the strain. I would suggest that a heavier truck should be given us which would be capable of handling greater tonnage per trip, as hauling from Lot 47 will be our greatest portage a round trip of ten miles and more.

The men who had the experience of using Ford trucks have found that in two years they were obliged to change them, and replace them with either International or Federal trucks.

I trust that these few suggestions will not be amiss and that the Department will not think that I am being in any way forward.

Thanking you and the Department for your kind attention to this matter.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
S. GEORGE'S INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL FOR INDIAN BOYS AND GIRLS

Supported by the New England Company. (The oldest English Missionary Society, founded 1649)

Lytton, B. C., February 12th, 1924.

Mr. Graham,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B. C.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have to make application to the Department for some sort of an office desk which I can keep locked.

With no way of isolation owing to building conditions, I cannot keep members of the staff out and the result is that my office equipment is borrowed at will. The situation is becoming a chronic nuisance.

On the other hand, with no place to keep books and papers of importance, one or two members of the staff have taken the opportunity from a busybody standpoint to go through books and papers, and consequently the business of the school has been circulated from a non-official source.

I would be obliged if you would endorse this and ask the Department to provide me, if possible, with a roll-top desk, with drawers on both sides in which I can keep school account books and other notes and letters of importance.

I am,

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Sir,

I herewith beg to enclose a letter from the principal of St. George's School, in which he makes a request for a roll-top desk.

I would strongly recommend that this be purchased for him, as Mr. Lett mentioned in his letter, owing to the crowded state of the school his private residence has to be used for the staff, with the result his office is made to free use of.

I have often commented to Mr. Lett on this and the only solution we can see, is to give him some means of locking up his books and papers.

I think perhaps we could get a second hand desk, from some of the secondhand stores, fairly cheaply.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, Feb. 20, 1924.

Sir:

I have your l-06 of the 12th instant, enclosing a communication from the Rev. Principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School, in which he requests that a roll-top desk be supplied for his office. I have noted that you may be able to secure a second hand desk that would be suitable and I should be pleased if you would make enquiries and forward for the Department's consideration a definite recommendation.

I have also your l-06 of the 13th instant, with reference to a truck for the institution. The Department is corresponding with the International Harvester Company, with a view to ascertaining the best price on their 2 or 2½ ton trucks.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B. C.

R

I herewith beg to enclose vouchers Nos. 420 I, 421 I and 422 I, amounting to $336.49, and $244.42, in favor of Wm. M. Orr, and $1054.28 in favor of the Pacific Coast Pipe Company, in connection with the expenses incurred in building the waterworks for the new barn at St. George's Industrial School.

You will notice from the pay-lists, that Mr. Wm. M. Orr, contractor, has entered himself up on the pay-lists as working full time with the men, as supervisor or foreman. I do not know whether it is customary for a contractor, who is working on a 10% basis, to put himself down full time as overseer as well or not. Mr. Orr did work a little in helping to lay the pipe, but the rest of the time merely acted as foreman.

Trusting enclosed vouchers will be found in order,

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

14th February 1924

Duncan Scott Esq: D.Litt.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Mr Mathews, the Governor of the Company, desires me to thank you for your letter of January 4th, and to inform you that it is considered by the Company desirable that the buildings at St George's School, Lytton, should be insured. Instructions have therefore been given to the agent who effected the previous insurance to see that the buildings are kept covered. The Company would be most grateful if you would kindly let them know what in your opinion is the sum for which the buildings should be insured at the present time. The original cost is unfortunately no guide in these days, as to the amount which would be required to replace them.

Thanking you in anticipation,

I am, dear Sir,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Charter Clerk.

Ottawa, Feb. 28, 1924.

Memorandum: Mr. Paget.

With reference to the account hereunder for a Delco generating plant for the St. George's Industrial School, I beg to say that this plant was bought and is being installed by Mr. C. L. Wain of Kamloops, on a proven cost plus ten per cent basis. As far as the materials are concerned we are paying this account direct. This was authorized by Mr. Scott on the recommendation of the Minister's office, and I gave instructions regarding the installation when I visited the St. George's School last fall.

You will observe by my telegram of December 5th, hereunder, that when authorizing the installation of the generating outfit, I requested Mr. Wain to obtain competitive prices and purchase to the best advantage. I did not consider that this matter would come under the regulations of the Purchasing Committee.

[Signature]

ARCHITECT.

Sir,

Having reference to your letter of February 21st, re extras amounting to $791.30 added to the new barn recently built at St. George's Industrial School, when Mr. Gurney Orr was here and discussed, with the Principal, Mr. Orr, the contractor and myself, the building of this new barn, he wrote a letter to the contractor and gave me a copy of same, in which these extras were authorized.

He told me at the time just to enter these up under item "Extras".

I am enclosing a copy of Mr. Gurney Orr's letter, which I trust explains the matter.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,

Orr, contractor for the new barn at St. George's School, which will speak for itself, together with particulars of extras approved by the Department.

March 1, 1924.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

On January 3rd, 1924, we supplied a model 320 Delco-Light plant to the St. George's Indian School, Lytton, B.C.

Your contractor in charge of this work, Mr. C. L. Wain, Kamloops, B.C., advised us at that time that this matter would receive prompt attention from your department. He advised us that you would settle direct with this Company and that remittance would in all probability be placed in the mail within thirty days from date of delivery.

Two months have now passed and we would be interested as to the probable date of your settlement.

Yours very truly,

BRUCE ROBINSON ELECTRIC.

[Signature]

Manager.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sir,—
I herewith beg to enclose voucher No. 1447 I, in favor of myself.

In regard to this purchase, I beg to state that by departmental letter number 165-0-5 dated February 20th, the Department advised me to ascertain what a suitable secondhand desk could be obtained for, and the matter would be given consideration.

I got quotations and one man, Mr. McCuaig wrote me that he could get me an excellent desk for $35.00, but as it had to be purchased right away he could not guarantee to have it kept for me.

As none of the other quotations came within double the price of this one, besides not being as suitable a desk, I took it upon myself to purchase this one, and paid for it.

The desk has arrived and is in excellent condition, practically as good as new, and is similar to ones they are asking over $100.00 for.

Trusting that the Department approves of my action in this matter, as it was too good a chance to lose,

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Hg/MD
Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 8th inst re Delco Lighting Plant supplied to the St Georges School Lytton, B.C., we advise you as follows.

On receipt of your telegram of Dec 5th I wrote to the Canadian Westinghouse Co, Candain General Electric, Bruce Robinson Electric Co, Canadian Fairbanks Morse Co, for quotations on a 3 to 5 K.W, 110 volt Generating Set direct connected to Gasoline or Kerosene Engine, quotations to be F.O.B, Lytton C.N.R, and to state time of delivery. Replies were received from Can, Fairbanks Morse, stating they had nothing of that size and could not quote.

Can Westinghouse Co, Advising they had nothing of that size listed at Vancouver but would quote from head office in about 10 days, nothing further received to date.

Canadian Allis Chalmers for C.G.E.Co, Quoteing on a 5 K.W, set water cooled complete with 160 amp hour Battery Price without sales tax F.O.B, Lytton $2,594.00

Shipment from factory 6 weeks from receipt of order.

Bruce Robinson Electric Co, Advising they did not make 5 K.W, Sets, and quoting on their Standard 3 K.W, Delco Lighting Set complete with 160 amp hour battery F.O.B,
Lyttom without sales tax $2,129.65

Delivery 2 weeks from receipt of order

Or as an alternative we can supply a 5 K.W., English Crude Oil Engine & Generator mounted on one base but belt driven, complete with 160 amp hour battery F.O.B., Lyttom $2,190.00

Delivery 2 weeks from receipt of order,

In considering the relative merits of the figures obtained it was advisable to keep before us the following points,

Reliability,
Simplicity of Operation,
Type of help available for operation,
Ease of obtaining Spare parts in case of break down,
Delivery if to be used this winter.

The Allis Chalmers Set requiring 6 weeks at factory and 2 to 3 weeks in transportation could not arrive until about the end of February, also this set was not self starting, Spare parts would have to come from Milwaukee, so we set it aside for something that could be obtained quicker.

The English Crude oil Engine, quotation appears favourable as to price. This engine has no positive ignition & is fired by the hot tube system and requires to be heated up before starting, is not self starting, requiring compressed air to start with, and requires somewhat expert operator to run it. The writer has had considerable experience with this type of engine on Irrigation Plants and fully realizing the difficulty of operation and cost of upkeep.
thought it would not be suitable for the St Georges School,
and therefore selected the 3 K.W. Delco Set because it
would fulfill all the requirements that was necessary,
This Plant was obtained and we had light in the residence
part of school on the 5th of January, and put the balance on
as fast as they was installed. It is now operating on all
lights and is giving good satisfaction both in the building
and outside.

The operation of this plant is very economical in operation
using 5 galls of gas or kerosene for 2 days which is
about one quarter the amount used for lamps.
This installation is now complete in every respect and the
final vouchers will be submitted in a few days,

Yours very truly

C. L. Weir
Electrical & Mechanical
Engineer

HG/MD
Ottawa, March 27, 1924.

Dear Mr. Bush:

I have your letter of the 14th ultimo and in reply I have to inform you that $55,000 is a rough valuation of the buildings at the Lytton Indian Residential School. Replacement costs would be about $75,000, but to build a modern institution and outbuildings would require an expenditure of at least $125,000.

I have valued the present buildings at $55,000; but you should know that the chapel, worth approximately $18,000, and the new $10,000 barn, which the Department has lately erected, are the only structures on the property which are in good condition.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

F. R. Bush, Esq.,
Charter Clerk,
New England Company,
26 Bloomsbury Sq.,
London, W.C., England.
Ottawa, March 27, 1924.

Sir:

I have to refer further to your No. 1-06 of the 13th ultimo, relative to a truck for the Lytton Indian Residential School. The Department has made some enquiries and it is found that an International truck is too expensive and authority cannot be given for this type of equipment. If a smaller truck would be satisfactory for the use of the school, please send me a night letter intimating the exact type required.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B. C.

Dear Sir:

During my visit at Kamloops investigating the conditions at St. Bartholomew's Hospital as requested by you, I took the opportunity of visiting St. George's School and seeing how the new electrical installation is working.

The Principal informs me that it is giving every satisfaction, and it is a great relief to them to be over the constant fear of fire.

I also inspected the new barn, which seems in every way satisfactory, and with which the Principal seems also to be very pleased.

Yours truly,

(Signed) S. Pragnell

Lytton, B. C.,

April 2nd, 1924

Sir,

I have departmental letter dated March 27th, in which you state that on making enquiries as to the price of an International truck, the Department finds it too expensive, and ask me for a recommendation on a smaller truck.

I have talked this matter over with the principal and he states that with the long and heavy hauls that he would have, it is really useless to buy a light truck. He considers that a two ton truck is really the lightest for the work and for economy's sake. The lighter truck would use practically as much gasoline and labor in operating it, as the heavier, and the difference in price of the heavier truck would be offset in a very short time.

The principal further advises me that now that he has not been able to have the use of this for the spring he can wait until July, but would certainly like to have one by then. If it is impossible to supply this size then I suppose we will have to do with a 1½-2 ton truck.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I would like to bring to your attention the great need of a touring car for the principal of St. George's Industrial School. Mr. Lett, when he came out here, brought his car with him, which car has been used steadily for the last two and a half years, and is now completely done.

Mr. Lett as you know has worked very hard and has raised the school to a very high standard, which has only been done by constant attention to duty. He has been practically on duty day and night running here, there and everywhere with his own car. This now practically refuses to go any longer.

Owing to the location of the farm and the great deal of work to be done with this and also with the school the car is practically indispensable, so he is now at his wits end to know how to get about. It is absolutely essential that he should have a car, and as he has now worn out his own, I think that the Department should replace it.

The old car could be turned in and would realize about $125.00 upon the purchase of a new one, and I sincerely trust that the Department will be able to see their way clear to do this, as it is too much to expect the principal to buy another car out of his own pocket.

Hoping to get an early and favorable reply,

I have the honor to be,

Sir

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

May 6, 1924.

Memorandum:

Rev. Mr. Lett, Principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School, has used his own Ford car in connection with his duties for the past 2½ years and it is now completely worn out. The agent recommends - and I concur - that a new car should be supplied for the principal and I wish to suggest that funds be found in the New England Company quarterly payment. Mr. Lett could be instructed to turn in his old car and realize $125 (estimated by the agent) towards the purchase of a new one. The balance would be approximately $550 and he could meet this from school finances and send the receipted account to the Department. We could then give him a grant from the New England Company money which would be deposited in a Trust Account.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, May 9, 1924.

Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your No. 3-06 of the 22nd ultimo, with reference to the advisability of providing a Ford car for the use of Rev. Mr. Lett, of the Lytton Indian Residential School. The Department proposes to retain in Ottawa, for replacements and repairs, etc., the New England Company quarterly grants and the Deputy Superintendent General has been pleased to authorize that the expenditure for the Ford touring car be taken from this fund.

The Rev. Mr. Lett should turn in his old car to the agent of the Ford Company and secure a new touring car for the best possible price. He should pay for this by School Cheque and send the receipted account, properly certified by yourself, to the Department. A cheque on the Trust Fund will then be issued in his favour.

Your obedient servant,

Lytton, B.C.,

May 20th, 1924.

Sir,

I have department's letter dated May 9th, advising me that I might purchase a Ford car for the principal of Lytton Industrial School.

I got prices from the Ford dealers on a car, which they gave me at $650.00, but would not take the Chevrolet as part payment.

I handed your letter to the principal and he has now just answered me, and I am enclosing his letter.

I might state that a Ford car in this vicinity is practically useless as the hills are far too heavy for a two geared car, and the braking system is not at all suitable. It would mean that the car would have to be relined practically every trip it made to Lot 47, as there is four miles steep hill to come down. The Ford car is quite all right for a city or flat country, but is quite unsuitable for a district like this.

Trusting the Department will reconsider this matter,

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

HC/MD
Lytton, B. C., May 20th, 1924.

Mr. H. Graham,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B. C.

Dear Mr. Graham:

Re the Department's offer to allow me to purchase a Ford Car out of the proceeds of the N.E.C. Grant to this school. I might say that we can ill afford at this time to lose this Grant as a whole, or even to the extent of $650, the price of said car, nevertheless, I shall endeavor, if possible, to carry on less this amount as I must have some means of conveyance other than horse and cart. This, of course, is providing the Department sees fit, after the following, to insist that a Ford Car must be installed.

While I have no personal objection to riding in a Ford, there are several reasons why it would not be economical to have one here when the initial cost would not be very great in the purchase of a Chevrolet, a three speed car. The difference in cost would not exceed $100 as correspondence from the Ford Agents shows that they do not want to handle the old car, while the Chevrolet people have offered me $150 for it on a new car. This means that I would have to pay $650 cash for the Ford and run the risk of selling my old car myself for whatever I can realize for it. I would much rather prefer to hand the old car over on a new one and have nothing more to do with it.

Again the expense of running a Ford around these hills in the way of lining brakes and gears, would be much greater. I can readily see where the Ford would spend a great deal of its time in the local garage instead of giving service to the school and as you know I have no time to wait on this kind of thing. If I was buying a car myself I certainly would not spend my money on a Ford car expecting it to give the best services in this country.

$650.00 plus $150.00 would be $800.00. The difference between this amount and a new Chevrolet is $50.00. I would be quite willing to pay this difference myself rather than expend a great deal of time waiting on a two speed car and after it is installed eternally fixing up some part that will not stand the strain of so much heavy hill work.

I trust the Department will see fit to change their decision allowing us to purchase or spend the above arranged amounts on a Chevrolet which will give the desired satisfaction.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
May 27, 1924.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

Two weeks ago, with your approval, the Department authorized the Rev. Principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School to purchase a Ford car, after turning in his old machine, and send the receipted account to the Department. The funds were to be found in the New England Company's quarterly grant for this institution. It is now reported that Mr. Lett's old car is a Chevrolet and that a three speed car is practically necessary for the hilly country in the neighborhood of the school. I know the situation myself and I agree that a new Chevrolet touring car would give much better service.

I should be pleased to have your authority to make a payment to the Rev. Mr. Lett from the New England Company grant of $680 in place of the promised $550. A Chevrolet touring car will cost $880. Mr. Lett will get $150 when he turns in his old one and is willing to add $50 from his own funds.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, May 27, 1924.

Sir:

I have your No. 3-06 of the 20th instant, enclosing a communication from the Rev. Principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School with reference to the purchase of a touring car. I have noted that a Chevrolet would give much better service than a Ford car and in reply I am pleased to inform you that the Department will allow $680 for the purchase of a Chevrolet. As was explained in my 165-0-5 of the 9th instant, the Rev. Principal should turn in his old car and secure a new one for the best possible price. He should make payment by school cheque and send the receipted account, properly certified by yourself, to the Department. A cheque for $680 on the Trust Fund, to which will be deposited the New England Company grants, will then be issued.

I have noted that a Chevrolet touring car will cost $880, that the Principal will receive $150 for his old car and is willing to add $50 from his own funds.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

CANADA
Having further reference to my letter of April 22nd, and Department's reply of May 9th, No. 165-0-5, re the motor car for the principal of St. George's Indian Industrial School, on the 20th inst., I replied to this, and enclosed a letter from the principal on the same subject, which we are now waiting to hear from.

I regret to report that on Thursday last, a very serious accident happened through this old car. The head teacher was taking five of the boys out in it, when the brakes failed to work, at a critical moment, with the result that they all went over an embankment, which completely wrecked the car. One boy had a dislocated shoulder, and the teacher and other boys were badly shaken up. It is only a miracle that they were not all killed.

The principal is now without any means of conveyance, and finds it most difficult to get around and attend to his work, without it.

I trust that the Department will give this matter their very favorable consideration and wire their intentions on receipt of this letter, if instructions have not already been sent me.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

S. GEORGE'S INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL FOR INDIAN BOYS AND GIRLS

Supported by the New England Company. (The oldest English Missionary Society, founded 1649)

Lytton, B.C., June 9th, 1924.

Mr. H. Graham,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Graham:

Two years ago this having season our horses ran away with the McCormick Mower breaking the gears and cracking the frame. We replaced the parts broken and the machine did good work the remainder of that season and last year. This year owing to the heavy crop of hay the frame being unable to stand the strain has given way.

I have taken it upon myself to purchase a new machine feeling that we could not afford to wait until we could get authorization from the Department, it being an emergency case. As you know we have a large acreage to cut this year and to depend absolutely on one mower would be too slow because of so much other work pending.

I bought this machine from the International people at Ashcroft getting the best terms possible.

I trust you will see fit to approach the Department with a view of getting a grant to cover price of this machine. I also trust they will be patient with me having in this case gone over their heads.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Sir:

I herewith beg to enclose voucher number 81, amounting to $118.75, in favor of Mark Dumond, together with a letter from the principal of St. George's Industrial School, which will speak for itself.

As the principal is having difficulty in financing the institution and getting the place out of debt, he finds it rather hard to meet these unforeseen expenses, and I would like to recommend that the Department assist him with this.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

HG/MD
Ottawa, June 21, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing a voucher amounting to $118.75 covering the cost of a mower purchased by the principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School, together with a communication regarding the purchase.

The urgency in making the purchase of this mower is not understood. The principal was, no doubt, aware that such equipment would be required and he should have obtained authority from the Department, through your office, before incurring the expenditure. In order to meet the requirements of the Government Contracts Supervision Committee and the Auditor General, it is necessary that competitive prices be obtained, and, when forwarding a voucher, it should be supported by an abstract showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted. This is required in order that full particulars be available, as required by the Auditor General. The Department cannot in future be responsible for the payment of accounts when the expenditure has not first been authorized, except in the case of purchases of the utmost necessity.

Please state whether the mower purchased is of Canadian manufacture and if competitive prices were obtained. If so, they should be forwarded for the information of the Department and the Auditor General. Payment of the account is being withheld until full information is received.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. D. McLean,
Aest. Deputy & Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B. C.
Dear Sir:

I have your letter of June 21st, acknowledging voucher for $118.75, covering cost of purchase of mower by the principal of the Lytton Industrial School.

You ask for reasons for the emergency for the purchase of this machine. I thought that this was fully explained in the principal's letter. The old machine had been broken and repaired, but it suddenly gave out during haymaking season and as the principal was going to Ashcroft to get his auto, he took it onto himself to purchase a new mowing machine. Although he knows about the requirements of the Government Contract Supervision Committee, he did not say one word to me, and therefore competitive prices were not obtained. I knew nothing of this purchase until the machine was here. The principal's excuse was that a machine had to be had at once, as they were in the middle of haymaking, and they could not wait to obtain competitive prices. The mower in question was bought from the International Harvester Company of Canada. The parts are assembled and put together by a Canadian firm, and are therefore looked upon as a Canadian make.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

INFORMATION OFFICE

At Lytton, B.C.

Aug. 2nd, 1924

Sir,

Having reference to former correspondence in connection with the needs for a truck for St. George's Industrial School.

The Principal has just been in and asked me to again approach the Dept. as the time is drawing near that we will have considerable hauling to do, we are in hopes of having considerable hay for sale, as well as potatoes, and it is next to impossible with the long haul to do this with horses, besides the great loss of time.

There will be the coal to haul from town, which is an uphill haul all the way, and is very slow and hard for horses.

Mr. Lett's touring car which he met with an accident with just before we purchased the new one, prevented this being turned in as a part payment, could be made into a very useful half ton truck for hauling groceries from town and shipping apples, tomatoes etc.

As it is now Mr. Lett uses the touring car, which in a very short time will be a wreck having to use it for this purpose.

The Principal has asked me to ask the Dept. if they would sanction having this car made into a small truck at a cost of about $125.00 the funds to come out of the New England grant.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant

Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Dept. of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, August 9th, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to the request of the Principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School for authority to incur an expenditure of approximately $125 in having the touring car which he used before the new one was purchased converted into a half ton truck.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the necessary alterations being made to convert this car into a truck for hauling purposes. The expenditure for the purpose should, if possible, not exceed the amount stated. This will be paid from the funds from the New England Co., grant upon receipt of a voucher, certified by you, covering the expenditure incurred. The Principal should see that the expense of the work is kept down to the lowest possible cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

GENERAL REMARKS:-

One of the needs of this school is a principal's residence. Mr. and Mrs. Lett feel that they would like to be able to have a home of their own, so that they might be free of the strain and turmoil of the life of the institution.

R. H. Cairns,
Insp.
Lyttion, B.C., Aug 20/24

Mr. H. Graham  
Indian Agent  
Lyttion  

Dear Mr. Graham-

We have this year a great deal more silage corn than will fill the present silo at the barn & I thought it would be an advantage if the old silo which is in perfectly good condition could be moved down so that it could be used to store the over plus of corn & filled with the third crop of alfalfa. The advantage of the second silo would be twofold. The silage could be used to substitute the summer pasturage & it would also be a time saver in harvesting the third crop of alfalfa & do away with the difficulty of curing this crop in bad weather which usually exists in the autumn ensuring better fodder.

The moving of the old silo would cost approximately $110.00 which amt. my financial status will not allow me to spend. I therefore wish to submit same to you for approval with a view of getting a grant from the Dept. to cover the same.

I would suggest that you ask the Dept. to wire their decision as it is now drawing nigh to the time when we should harvest the corn.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal
Sir:-

I herewith beg to enclose a letter from Mr. Lett, principal of St. George's School, asking for some assistance to move the silo from the old barn to the new one.

When applying for the new barn, I might say, I made application for two silos, but only one was given us, and we find that we have too much ensilage this year for the one and the second one can be put to good advantage.

Within the next two years we hope to have the new barn completely filled with milking cows, and when we have this, the two silos will not hold a bit too much ensilage. In talking this over Mr. Lett suggested that this money might be taken from the New England grant.

At any rate I would strongly recommend that this be approved and if the Department does, will you kindly wire me, as it is necessary to get this up as soon as possible.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

Mr. William Orr, the contractor for the barn at St. George's School, reports to me that he is $140.00 short in the final payments.

I have gone into this matter very carefully and I find that vouchers 421 I amounting to $356.49, and 422 I amounting to $244.42, amounting to $580.91, were sent in from this office. The Department sent Mr. Orr a cheque for $440.11 on these two vouchers, which left a balance due him of $140.80, the amount which he claims is short.

These vouchers were in connection with the water works and why the Department deducted this amount I do not know.

Trusting that you will put this right with Mr. Orr and send him a cheque for the balance due,

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

September 17th, 1924.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 8th instant, in which you report that Mr. William Orr, Contractor for Construction on the barn at St. George's School considers he is short $140.80 in the amount due him for work on the building, I beg to inform you that the amount mentioned was deducted from Mr. Orr's account, as it is considered that in view of the fact that he has been allowed a percentage on the expenditure incurred he is not entitled to wages. The amount deducted was made up as follows:

Wages . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $128.00
Account on wages . . . . . . . . $12.80

$140.80

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
(J.D. McLean),
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.
Ottawa, September 20, 1924.

WITH CHEQUE

Sir,-

Referring to your letter of the 5th instant regarding the amount ($140.50) retained from Mr. Wm. Orr when payment of his accounts was made for work on the barn at St. George's School, I beg to say that, in making settlement the Department allowed Mr. Orr 10% commission on the total cost of the work. It was considered, therefore, that he should not also be paid wages as per voucher No. 421-1, but, after looking further into the matter it appears that Mr. Orr performed the services of a workman in addition to having oversight as a contractor, and consequently, the Department has allowed him payment of $128.00 by the cheque herewith inclosed for personal work. He has not been allowed commission on his own work. It is hoped that this payment will be regarded as a satisfactory adjustment of Mr. Orr's claim.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge your night letter of the 21st instant, relative to an ensilage cutter and blower required at the Lytton Indian Residential School. I have to confirm my answering telegram of today's date, as follows:

"Purchase to best advantage ensilage cutter for Lytton School."

H. Graham, Esq.,

Lytton, B. C.
Sir:

I beg to confirm the following nightlettergram sent you in connection with the ensilage cutter and blower at St. George's School, Lytton.

Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

St. George's School ensilage cutter and blower completely broken down; and still about one hundred and twenty tons of ensilage to cut. May I purchase new one, price about one hundred and fifty dollars, may be allowed something on the old machine. Can be charged against New England grant. Please wire reply. Urgent.

(signed) "H. Graham, Indian Agent."

In regard to this I beg to state that we had just been started two days cutting ensilage when the machine broke down completely. Something must have got into it, and the whole machine was practically wrecked. We sent to Vancouver to see if new parts could be had, but they wired back that they could not supply them there, but might get them in the East. The machine has been in use for a great number of years and is an old model, and as we have at least 120 tons of ensilage still to cut, we thought that it would be very much better to purchase a new machine, rather than run the risk of not being able to replace the parts in the East.

I trust that the Department will see their way clear to granting this request as it is a much needed machine at the present time. The Canadian Fairbanks-Morse advised us that they might be able to allow us something on the old machine.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, November 4, 1924.

Dear Mr. Lett:

Your general letter of October 15th has caused me much concern. His Lordship the Bishop of Ottawa and Mr. Perrier were in my office yesterday and we discussed remedial measures at some length. Relative to your general financial condition, I believe you have done as well as could be expected, considering the difficulties. There is being directed to you under separate cover a cheque for $1270, which is on hand from the New England Company. Please use this for outstanding accounts, so that some of the worries of current financing will be relieved.

To further release per capita earnings for regular current expenses, you should request authority for all repairs and replacements other than those of a minor nature. Whenever funds are available, favourable consideration will be given to meeting these costs from Appropriation or future payments from the New England Company.

I understand from your letter that you are in favour of capital expenditure in connection with:

1. Hogpen and henhouse.
2. Milch cows, hogs and chickens.
3. Employees' residence.
4. Bath and toilet accommodation for two residences.
5. Principal's residence.
6. Proper living quarters for boys.

I believe funds can be found for some of these needs now and I am prepared to place an item in the Estimates for the more costly undertakings. If the Government allows the item the work could be undertaken next spring. Give serious consideration to the various questions and telegraph me, estimating the cost concerning what you would like to undertake immediately.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6464, file 888-5, part 1)
Indicate if the building activity you request in your telegram can be undertaken by day labour, under your supervision and that of the Indian agent. Further, let me know if stock should be purchased this fall, as I notice you have plenty of feed.

In the light of your letter, I consider that one of the most important requirements is the provision of a residence for yourself and family. You might let me know if a building of this type could be erected now and indicate the probable duration of the building season at Lytton. Upon receipt of your telegram, I will endeavour to secure the authority of the Superintendent General for the activity that is considered necessary now, provided the funds are available.

As it may not be possible to provide a new main building at Lytton in the near future, I am inclined to ask for a vote for a boys' dormitory and playroom combined. Please let me know by letter what you think of such a building and indicate whether it would be satisfactory to place it on the site that would be suitable for a new main building. We could perhaps use such a structure for classroom purposes in the future. In your letter you might intimate whether or not residence accommodation could be provided in the main building for the two employees who are not well housed, if the boys' dormitories, wash rooms, etc., were released by the provision of a special boys' building.

I was very pleased to learn that you have done so well on the farm and I wish to assure you of my active interest and assistance.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Re Estimates forwarded you by night lettergramme.

I might say that these estimates were roughly put together. I have however tried to give you the approximate cost including freight cartage & hauling of material for building & gravel for cement work.

My suggestion to wait over until the spring to commence operations is twofold. The winter has this year set in very early as since the first of the month we have had considerable snow & frost. Secondly that during the interval to get everything in readiness, would possibly lessen the cost by at least $2000.00 Dollars, as during the slack months of Jan. & Feb., we could, with our own teams do the hauling & excavating. A purchasing Agent could be had in Mr. Orr of Chilliwack who could by close observation pick up, in Car Load lots, the lumber needed. Cement could be shipped in by Car Load this would save considerable in freight charges.

With all the work going on at the same time, money could be saved on Plumbing & Plastering &c., as the one firm could be given the work, & having it done at the same time would save train fares for men & the whole job would be a fairly good pick up for one Firm.

I would not be able intelligently to supervise the work & would therefore suggest that Mr. Orr be given the supervision, & the work done by Day Labor on a cost plus basis.

I have not taken the Boys' Dormitory into consideration as I am dealing fully with this in a further report.

I omitted to say that we needed the cows as soon as purchase could be made. These cows to freshen shortly, if possible to obtain. This, I think, would not be a hard problem & could be had very reasonable in price, as feed is not in great abundance in the valley. We should then be able to turn over some ready cash which is so much needed.

Thanking you for hearing & interest & trust the above will to some degree explain the contents of telegramme of last evening.

Yours very obediently,

[Signature]

Principal
Ottawa, November 26, 1924.

Dear Mr. Lett:

Upon receipt of your letters with reference to building activity at the Lytton Indian Residential School, I immediately made arrangements to ask Parliament for a substantial vote which could be used during the coming building season. I have discussed a proposed programme with Mr. Warner and Mr. Orr and it is my aim to erect a farmer's residence, a hen house and a hog pen on the new site as soon as weather permits next spring. This activity could be undertaken by a competent builder, who could purchase the materials and supervise the work as foreman.

I suggest that the residence near the present school, which would be vacated by the farmer, be decorated and fitted up as a temporary home for yourself and family. A septic tank, plumbing and whatever else is needed could be provided. A cold storage building is, no doubt, needed; but my thought is that this could wait until it could be placed on the new site.

I am asking both Parliament and the New England Company for funds to erect a portion of a new main building. The wing would contain heating plant, dining room, kitchen and assembly hall. Until the main wing is erected, the dining room, kitchen and assembly hall could be used as boys' quarters.

It is true that such an arrangement would be somewhat inconvenient at mealtime, but the general supervision ought not to be more difficult. The farmer could be living near the new wing and the new barn and temporary quarters could be provided for another male officer with the boys. I believe that this arrangement would effect a saving in the long run and I will await with interest your answer to this communication. Mr. Indian Agent Graham is receiving a copy for his information.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B. C.

Ottawa, December 9th, 1924.

Rev. Sir:

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in a report on his recent inspection of the Lytton Residential School, draws attention to the condition of a drain which if not given immediate attention may become a source of menace to the health of the pupils.

I have to request that you will arrange to have the drain referred to by the Inspector thoroughly cleaned out and put in a good sanitary condition and any repairs required made in order to provide against any danger from an outbreak of typhoid. I am sure you will realize the necessity of having this drain put in proper order at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.
Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring to yours of the 26th ultimo, I have read the contents with interest & must say that I thoroughly appreciate the proposed programme of building mapped out for erection in the spring. We are in great need of such equipment & needless to say that I shall endeavor to make each a payable proposition.

May I ask if there is anything I might be able to do in the way of preparation such as excavating & drawing of gravel. I believe the men could make time to do some of this work later on in the season.

Re. the possibility of fitting out the present residence occupied by one of the farm hands to be used temporarily for a Principal's Residence cannot be carried out to any degree of satisfaction, as this shack is a small log house & is already beginning to fall to pieces. This being the reason why I asked that a new residence be built for the farm hand. The building is no longer occupiable.

I trust you will pardon my frankness but I wish you could see the building & you would easily realise the fruitlessness of your suggestion. It really would be throwing money away.

I might say that building a Principal's residence on the new sight would not, to any great degree, hinder my work & connection with the present school Building. My whole aim is to get Mrs. Lett & the younger away from the present environment. This cannot come too soon as it would give better satisfaction & more contentment & consequently better service. The old house which would be vacated is well down on the farm & not far off the new sight hence repairing this would not make much difference in so far as convenience is concerned.

I believe the right step is being taken regarding the commencement of a new School & I trust & pray that you will be able to accomplish your aim. The advantages would, I believe offset the disadvantages. We at least could house the older boys thus separating them from the smaller. They would also be in the centre of operations & could be supervised by one of the farm hands together with one of the teachers. This would do away with the position of House-master thus making a substantial saving. The Matron would be able to handle the smaller boys. There would be more room for playgrounds & rooms hence easier & better supervision.

Thanking you very sincerely,

Yours very obediently

[Signature]
Principal
Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of Nov. 23rd, enclosing a copy of a letter signed by Mr. Duncan C. Scott and addressed to the Principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School.

I have discussed this matter very fully with the Principal, and it is very gratifying to learn that the Department intend erecting the farmer's residence, hen house and hog pen, as soon as the weather permits in the spring. We are certainly very much in need of all these and they will allow a profit being made for the school from these sources.

In regard to the suggestion that the Principal take over the farmers cottage that is to be vacated, this is quite out of the question, as it is an old log building that has been condemned, and has really become uninhabitable.

It is certainly great news to us to hear that it is proposed to ask for an appropriation, in order to start the main wing for the new school. When this is completed, it will certainly get over a great many of our difficulties, as the boys quarters as suggested could be taken care of there.

It might not be out of place here to mention the water shortage that is threatening us, at the present school site. Everything possible has been done to get all the water available collected together, but with all that it looks as if it might run short, as some of the springs, that used to run a good head of water have completely dried up. A great deal depends now on the severity of the winter, if we have it very cold, it may dry up some of the springs now running, but if it remains a fairly open winter they may not be affected.

Your obedient servant,

(H.Graham)
Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, December 15, 1924.

Dear Mr. Lett:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the proposed building programme at the Lytton Indian Residential School. I note that the farm hands' residence could not be fitted up as a temporary principal's home.

It is extremely desirable that the principal live in a residence that is attached to the boys' wing. The home can be planned as if it were a detached building, but one wall is that of the main building. One door, admitting into the institution on the ground floor is all that is required. You will understand the advantage of this arrangement in the matter of supervision.

It is, therefore, not advisable to erect a principal's residence until the boys' wing of the main building is being built. I have to suggest, however, that a farmer's residence be erected on the new site at Lytton and that this building be occupied temporarily by yourself and family.

If we are able to build a portion of a new main building, as indicated in the third paragraph of my letter of the 28th ultimo, the older boys could use this as living quarters and temporary accommodation could also be found, no doubt, for a farm hand and one of the teachers.

As soon as building is possible next spring, the hen house and hog pen could be erected on a day labour basis. A contract could be let for the farmer's residence and the wing of the main building, if the funds are provided. There will be no advantage in any excavating or hauling of gravel for work that is to be done by contract. You might direct to the Department rough sketches of a suitable hen house and a hog pen.

In a separate letter, I shall be pleased if you will indicate what accommodation should be provided in the new main building. The number of pupils that you are confident of securing should be stated and the number of officers who will live in the building should be mentioned.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B. C.

Sir:

The Reverend Principal of St. George's School, showed me, a short time ago, your letter to him in connection with the proposed starting of the new building in connection with this institution.

It is very gratifying to note that it is your intention, if possible, to get an appropriation put through to start the first unit this coming spring. The last four days have shown how very essential it is that a new building be installed as soon as possible. The present building is completely done as far as housing anyone during the winter. The heating plant is quite incapable of heating this building sufficiently. It has been running at full capacity ever since the cold weather started, and the highest that they can get the temperature in any room is 52° and in some of the rooms it was only registering as high as 36°. The members of the staff are to be seen going about their duties inside the building with overcoats on, and I am very much afraid that it will be difficult to keep the staff over another winter in this building. If there is a chance of getting the building started, would it not be possible to get the whole building built at once, as it is not fair to either staff or pupils to have them housed in such a cold building as the present one is.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

HG/MD
I hope you will pardon me for submitting a report at this time, but as you have stated you are expecting to ask for appropriations for the beginning of a new school, I thought the following would perhaps be of some use toward getting out a report on further conditions existing at the school.

The weather has dropped from 64 degrees above on Sunday evening last, and now registers 12 below zero this morning. Since Monday morning, we have been suffering terribly with the cold, not being able to obtain sufficient heat, owing to the fact that our heating-system is over capacitated.

Have not been able to allow the children to occupy the schoolrooms, as the temperature there has registered a minimum of 32 degrees, and a maximum of 52 yesterday noon, with the sun streaming through the windows. This condition of affairs is not by any means ideal, nor conducive to the work, and health of children and teachers. The children are in the midst of their Christmas Exams, and last night on entering the senior schoolroom, I noticed that the Senior Teacher was trying, with what results I do not know, to conduct an exam with the temperature at 50 degrees.

This condition is general throughout the building, all departments being more or less stopped through the intense cold, which, should we have an adequately heated plant, would not be minded at all.

There is no gainsaying the fact that the age and condition of repair of this building adds to the labour of heating it, as there is hardly a wall in the place that does not let the wind and cold blow through it like a piece of cheesecloth; the windows are ill-fitting and the sills loose; doors have to be padded to try in some way to keep the drafts down.

Yesterday morning the doctors appeared on the scene, prepared to operate on the children selected for the removal of tonsils. Needless to say they were unable to think of operating under the existing condition of the temperature. We were unable to select one room in the whole building which we could heat to a degree of heat which would warrant these operations, and then would follow the return of the children after the operation to the cold dormitories. No doubt you will receive in due course, a report on their attempt and findings.
Duncan C Scott, Esq.,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

The building, from a living standpoint is almost an impossibility, and it is only under the feeling that, having a promise of the commencement of a new school, that myself and staff can carry on at all, under such existing circumstances.

I sincerely trust that the above will be of some help towards opening up the hearts of members of the Legislature when the time comes for voting the necessary money to carry on this work. People do not seem to realise the conditions under which men in the field are obliged to labour.

Sincerely yours,

(Rev) [Signature]

PRINCIPAL.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the general unsuitability of the main building at the Lytton Indian Residential School and the desirability of completing a main building at the first opportunity. There is no probability that funds will be provided for a complete main building next year, as there are so many pressing claims on Parliamentary Appropriation. It is hoped, however, that a start will be made on the new plant.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the 17th instant, and I note with regret that the recent cold snap has resulted in a season of considerable hardship to the staff and pupils at the Lytton Indian Residential School. The facts presented in your communication will strengthen our request for funds to enable us to commence a new building next year.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Mr. Duncan G. Scott,
Dept. Sect. Gen. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Re letter No. 838-5 of Dec. 15th last; I may say that I have hesitated to answer same at once as I wished to consider thoroughly the proposition of occupying the farm residence which you purpose in building with the new addition Unit if you are able to put estimates through for the erection of same.

I quite see your point in the question of supervision. On the other hand I hesitate somewhat in moving into this new residence as from the point of view of living quarters this man is existing under by no means ideal conditions & it is only that me & his wife have been looking forward to moving out of the old shack that he has exercised such patience. We, myself & Mrs. Lett with the baby who is now a very spoiled child, will have to try & carry on in our present abode & under present existing conditions with the sincere hope that no ill effects may develop. It is a rather hard two years future, or perhaps more to look forward to but in talking the matter over with Mrs. Lett we have concluded to make the best of it for the time. This may not be a final outlook on the situation as when the time comes & the farm residence has materialized circumstances may be such that might warrant our occupying it temporarily.

There is no reason why room could not be provided for two members of the staff who would be able to supervise & attend to the needs of the boys housed in the new quarters.

I trust you will see in the above my view & feel certain that you will exercise your utmost to have us changed around at the earliest possible period.

Yours very obediently,

[Signature]

Ottawa, Feb. 25, 1925.

Sir,-

With reference to your letter of the 2nd ultimo enclosing sketches for a hog pen and chicken house, I am sending you today herewith literature relating to hen houses and hog pens as published by the Department of Agriculture.

With regard to the poultry house I think the permanent laying house which I have worked with blue pencil would be more suitable and economical to construct than the one shown in your sketch. You will notice that a space is provided for slats in the ceiling in which to place straw. This is for the purpose of absorbing the moisture, which as you know is a very great advantage in a poultry house in the winter months.

With reference to the erection of these buildings I would ask you to furnish me with your estimate of the cost and let me know if you are prepared to undertake the work yourselves providing the Department allows you the services of one competent carpenter.

J. R. Lett, Esq.,
Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have this spring to purchase 500 lbs. Alfalfa seed which at 30¢ per lb. will run me into a bill of $150.00. It is necessary that this seed should be sown & if it is at all possible I would be very grateful if the Dept. would be responsible for this amt. as I feel I can ill-afford to carry same at this present time. Except for the rotation of about 30 acres of land it has been my aim to seed all the remaining available land to Alfalfa as it is without doubt the most paying crop here outside of fodder corn.

I trust you will see fit to present this request to the Dept.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal
Sir:-

I herewith beg to enclose a letter from the principal of St. George's School, asking for some assistance towards purchasing alfalfa seed, in order that he may sow down about thirty acres this spring.

In regard to this application I might say that the principal has about got this farm on a paying basis, but he finds it difficult to finance extra expense of this nature, and I would like to recommend that he be given this assistance.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

HG/MD
Ottawa, March 4, 1925.

Sir:

I have your No. 1-06 of the 26th ultimo, enclosing a request from the principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School for a grant of approximately $150 for the purchase of alfalfa seed. The Department has given favourable consideration and you may authorize the principal to purchase 500 lbs. of seed, after securing competitive prices if possible. When you are certifying to the account, please mark it to be paid from Account 460. This is the account in which the New England Company grants are deposited.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B. C.
Ottawa, March 5, 1925.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
St. George's Indian School,
Lytton, B.C.

Reference hog pen and chicken house, are you prepared to supervise erection of buildings, provided the Department pays for labour, also wire me your estimate of cost as this was not given in your letter.

A. F. MacKenzie.

HG/MD
March 24th, 1925.

MEMORANDUM

HON. CHARLES STEWART.

There is an item in the Estimates for Indian Education, 1925-26, to provide funds to commence new buildings at the Lytton Indian Residential School in British Columbia. The New England Company, of London, Eng., give the Department financial assistance for the conducting of this school. Their grants are deposited in a special account and are used when needed.

The Reverend Principal, in whom I have considerable confidence, wishes to proceed immediately with the erection of a henhouse and hogpen. He has submitted a proposal for two large and complete outbuildings, which will cost approximately £2,300. The Principal will arrange for the activity on a day labour basis. I propose to take the funds necessary for these two outbuildings from the New England Company grant, and I shall be pleased to have your concurrence.

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.
March 24th, 1925.

MEMORANDUM

HON. CHARLES STEWART,

There is an item in the Estimates for Indian Education, 1925-26, to provide funds to commence new buildings at the Lytton Indian Residential School in British Columbia. The New England Company, of London, Eng., give the Department financial assistance for the conducting of this school. Their grants are deposited in a special account and are used when needed.

The Reverend Principal, in whom I have considerable confidence, wishes to proceed immediately with the erection of a henhouse and hogpen. He has submitted a proposal for two large and complete outbuildings, which will cost approximately $2,200. The Principal will arrange for the activity on a day labour basis. I propose to take the funds necessary for these two outbuildings from the New England Company grant, and I shall be pleased to have your concurrence.

APPROVED:

Chas Stewart

Deputy Superintendent General.

Ottawa, June 16th 1924

Drawn Cheque in favour of Receiver General for Credit School vote for refund of vouchers 3K, 4K, 5K, 6K, and 7K and 8K

J.W.S.
Sir:

I have your 3-06 of the 8th instant, enclosing four vouchers with reference to building activity at the Lytton Indian Residential School. These are being paid, with the exception of your voucher No. 47 K, in favour of the school, for $235.00. I consider that the management at Indian residential schools should supply whatever labour and materials they can, without cost to the funds at the disposal of the Department. The account in question is returned herewith. Please explain to the Rev. Principal.
