Ottawa, July 6, 1925.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Three Thousand Dollars is available for the erection of a residence for the staff at the Lytton Indian Residential School, in British Columbia. The Rev. Principal, who has lately visited the Department, believes that by using the school staff and some of the older boys two small cottages for the staff can be built for this amount. I should be pleased to have your authority to instruct the Indian Agent, in conjunction with the Rev. Principal, to purchase the necessary materials and to erect the buildings by day labour.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.
Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart.

Three Thousand Dollars is available for the erection of a residence for the staff at the Lytton Indian Residential School, in British Columbia. The Rev. Principal, who has lately visited the Department, believes that by using the school staff and some of the older boys two small cottages for the staff can be built for this amount. I should be pleased to have your authority to instruct the Indian Agent, in conjunction with the Rev. Principal, to purchase the necessary materials and to erect the buildings by day labour.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Authorized

July 8, 1925.
Ottawa, July 30, 1925.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have to inform you that the Rev. Mr. Lett, Principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School, when in Ottawa a few weeks ago, discussed with the Department the erection of two cottages on the new school site for the staff. It was understood that one of these homes would be used by the Rev. Principal and his family for the time being.

I am pleased to state that $3,000 is available for the purpose of erecting the two cottages and the Department Architect is convinced that the Rev. Mr. Lett's plans for these two buildings will be satisfactory to the Department. You, in conjunction with the Rev. Principal, are authorized to purchase the materials necessary for these two buildings, after securing competitive prices. When you are submitting certified accounts in duplicate, in favour of the firms given the business, you should attach memoranda showing those asked to quote and the prices quoted. Labour returns, in duplicate, should be kept for any labour employed, showing the hours of the men engaged and their receipts for wages. A supply of these time sheets is being directed to you under separate cover and there is also being directed to you an accountable cheque for $800 with which to pay labourers. It is understood that the school staff, teams and older boys will work whenever possible on the two cottages. None of the funds directed to you should be used for the payment of materials. These accounts should be directed to the Department for payment.

Both you and the Rev. Principal, who is receiving a copy of this letter, should keep in mind the fact that only $3,000 is available for this purpose and that the expenditure should be kept within this amount.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B. C.
INDIAN OFFICE

At... Lytton, B.C.

August 12th, 1925,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of yours of July 30, 1925, in regard to the building of the two cottages for St. George's Indian Industrial School, Lytton, also time sheets for labour employed, and cheque 2227 amounting to $300.00, with which to pay the labourers.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6464, file 888-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
October 10th, 1925.

Dear Sir,-

I have your E.T. of the last instant relative to the excise tax on an automobile chassis purchased by the Lytton Indian Residential School.

This institution is under the absolute control of the Dominion Government. The property is owned jointly by the New England Company of London, England and the Dominion Crown. This Department hopes to purchase the equity of the New England Company in the near future. The current expenses at the present time are divided approximately as follows:-

Indian Affairs - 85 per cent.
New England Co. - 15 per cent.

Yours truly,

J. D. McLEAN
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

F.F. Farrow, Esq.,
Deputy Minister,
Department of Customs & Excise,
Ottawa.

CANADA
Sir—

Enclosed please find time sheet for work done on two cottages built at St. George's School.

You will notice from the statement enclosed that the full amount came to $1330.75. From this had to be deducted the amount of board which was credited to the school, of $233.00, leaving a balance of $1097.75 due for wages. I have paid out the $800.00 advanced and sent to me by the Department, and Mr. Lett advanced the difference, of $297.75, for which I am enclosing a voucher, No. 301K. Mr. Lett advises me that the Department has this amount to the credit of the buildings in Ottawa.

Trusting that these will be found in order,

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

HG/MD
December 2nd, 1925.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th November, with which you forwarded certain pay-sheets, etc., in connection with work on the cottages adjacent to Lytton Residential School. The paylists in question should be made out in duplicate in accordance with instructions contained in official letter of the 30th July. There is an error of $20.00 in the addition of the pay-sheet for the 31st October. If you received $297.75 from Mr. Lett to complete the payment of men's wages you should forward a receipt for him to be attached to the voucher, for that amount, which you submitted in his favour.

The expenditure authorized in the official letter of July 30th was $3,000.00, but the accounts amount to $1,876.22 and the pay-sheets to $1,310.75, or an aggregate of $3,186.97, which is $186.97 in excess of the amount authorized.

Your obedient servant,

(J.D. McLean)
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. Graham, ESQ.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.
December 2nd, 1925

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th November with which you forwarded certain vouchers, one of which is in favour of Mr. Wm. M. Orr, amounting to $108.40 and covers expenditure in connection with the erection of two cottages at St. George's Residential School, and in reply I may say that before dealing with the matter of payment, the Department desires particulars regarding the charge in the said voucher for eight railway fares from Chilliwack to Lytton and return. You should state whether Mr. Orr made the said trips purely on business in connection with the erection of the cottages or whether he went from Chilliwack to Lytton to transact private business. If the latter was the case it is considered that the Department should not be charged with his travelling expenses.

The question of the payment of the voucher mentioned will not be dealt with until your report is received.

Your obedient servant,

(J.D. McLean)
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.
St. George's Indian Residential School
Supported by the New England Company
(The oldest English Missionary Society, founded 1649)

Lytton, B.C., Dec 1st/25

Mr. D.C. Scott
Dep. Sup. General
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Re. your telegram concerning the possible postponement of the building of the New School. I answered same stating that "Delay would mean great inconvenience and grave risk practically impossible to wait." From the point of view of the former:
1. The school is now so far away from the farm that the boys are obliged to drive one half mile to do the milking. This means out of bed at five o'clock in the A.M. in order to be back for breakfast with the milk for seven.
2. In some cases when the farm work is being done on the north east of the farm the men & boys are obliged to travel about one mile to their work. This naturally curtails a great deal of lost time & money in the payment of staff whereas if the school were moved to the new site the greater part of this lost time would be taken up in actual work and the school would then be situated in the middle of operations. By this move being done it would not only save me the worry of seeing so much unnecessary waste of time but would also help financially.
3. I am now living one half mile away from the school having just completed the cottage which I spoke of occupying for the few intervening months expecting the School to be built on block or the greater part beginning next spring. This will continue for over a year or perhaps two the extra running entailed.
4. The constant fear of staff resigning owing to the unalterable inconveniences through unsanitary conditions & lack of equipment.
5. Having to haul water to auxilliate the present exhaustive supply & very often necessitating the carrying of water to flush closets in the dormitories.

Grave Risk:
1. Overcrowding of dormitories and the evils attached to it.
2. No separation older from younger pupils. We have what we might call divisions in the boys dormitories but the girls are all together.
3. No isolation for sick. Contagious diseases must needs be let run riot.
4. Cold building. Drafty. Heating system overradiated. Children at the present time have heavy colds & do not seem able to shake them. Two children are in the hospital having developed pneumonia.
5. Insufficient water for sanitary purposes & fire protection. Seeing irrigation ditch which is full of disease germs keeping us in constant dread of disease outbreak.
6. Insufficient sanitary equipment.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6464, file 888-5, part 1)
The newly appointed Bishop of Cariboo has lately visited the school & has cabled the N.E. Co. asking them to refrain from putting anything into the way of the Dept. which might hinder you from building the coming spring. The Bishop was not a little disappointed at the state of the buildings on the whole especially noting the foundations of the old part of the building. No doubt you have heard something from him by this time. The N.E.C.O. appointed him visiting Bishop before he left England & as this will be his Diocesan School he is interested in its welfare.

I do hope you will be able to go on with the building next spring we need it so badly from so many viewpoints. The building of a New School would relieve us all of so many difficulties and risks to the health & morals of the children.

Yours very sincerely

[Signature]

PRINCIPAL
Ottawa, December 12th, 1925.

Rev. Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the last instant with reference to the urgent need for a new main building at the Lytton Indian Residential School. Your representations will not be overlooked by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.

CANADA
Sir,

I have yours of the 2nd, returning pay sheets in connection with the work on the two cottages at St George's School, to be made out in duplicate.

I now beg to enclose these in duplicate together with a fresh Voucher #301K in favor of the Rev. A. R. Lett for $277.75 amount advanced by him to pay the balance due the Carpenters, together with an official receipt given to Mr Lett for this amount.

Trusting everything will be found in order.

Your obedient servant,

(H.Graham)
Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Dept. of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.
Ont.
Sir,—
I have yours of the 2nd. inst enquiring about the eight railway fares charged up for on Voucher submitted in favor of Mr Wm.M.Orr for $108.40.
In reply I beg to state that there are no carpenters in this vicinity, and that we had to import them from Chilliwack, and these fares were solely for the men coming to work on the two cottages.

Your obedient servant,

(H.Graham)
Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.
Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 11th instant, I beg to say that the voucher for $277.75 which you submitted in favour of the Rev. A.R. Lett, of St. George's School, Lytton, as an advance on wages paid carpenters in building cottages in connection with the school, has been paid. The paylists for wages have been credited against the advance, but I may say that the note on the paylists in regard to $233.00 for board of men is not sufficiently explicit. Kindly report in the matter stating whether the amount was deducted from the men's wages and paid to the school, or whether the men were boarded at the school without charge. The matter should be made perfectly clear.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sirs:-

Upon the instructions of Rev. R. A. Lett, who is in charge of the work for St. George's School at Lytton, B. C., we have shipped and charged goods amounting to Six Hundred and Ninety-one Dollars and Sixty-eight Cents, ($691.68), to be paid for through the Department of Indian Affairs.

As the prices were quoted on a net cash basis we would appreciate your letting us have your cheque promptly in the above amount.

Thanking you in anticipation,

we are,

Yours respectfully,

KYDD BROS.

HFK/DB
Ottawa, 25th December, 1925.

Sirs,

I beg to transmit herewith an account of $691.68 received at the Department from Messrs Kydd Bros., of Vancouver, together with copy of the covering letter. You will observe that the account was incurred in connection with St George's School Lytton. I shall be glad to have you look into this matter and report, without delay.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. Graham Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of departmental letter dated December 23rd, asking about a deduction of $233.00 which was shown as a footnote on the paylist accompanying a voucher sent in in favor of A.R. Lett for payment of wages, on two cottages built at St. George's Industrial School.

In reply I beg to state that this amount was the total deducted from the men's wages for board, by the Rev. A.R. Lett, during the whole time that they were working. The note was made on the paylist just to show that the men had paid board out of the amount paid them as wages.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
